Subsubsection Text: This offering memorandum contains forward-looking statements that are forward-looking and, therefore, subject to risks and uncertainties. All statements other than statements of historical fact or relating to present facts or current conditions included in this offering memorandum are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include statements concerning our plans, objectives, goals, strategies, future events or performance, capital expenditures, financing needs, ability to fund operations, intentions relating to acquisitions, competitive strengths and weaknesses, and business strategy; the Merger; and other information that is not historical information. Words such as “may,” “will,” “expect,” “intend,” “estimate,” “anticipate,” “believe,” “should,” “forecast,” “project,” “target” or “plan” or terms of similar meaning are also generally intended to identify forward-looking statements. However, the absence of these words does not mean that a statement is not forward-looking. Forward-looking statements are based on current expectations of future events. The forward-looking statements are, and will be, based on management’s current views and assumptions regarding future events and operating performance and speak only as of their dates. We caution that these statements are subject to numerous important risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors, some of which are beyond our control, that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. Investors are therefore cautioned not to place undue reliance on any forwardlooking statements. Forward-looking statements are only made as of the date hereof, and we assume no obligation, and disclaim any obligation, to update forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances occurring after the date hereof, except as required by applicable law or regulations. The following are some important factors that could cause our actual results to differ from current expectations: - general economic and other conditions, including the COVID-19 pandemic, and accordingly, volatility in and disruption to both the U.S. and global economic environment; - the financial stability of our customers, some of whom serve cyclical industries; - the financial stability of our suppliers and our ability to obtain timely and cost-effective raw materials and other inputs used in the manufacturing process; - the inability to meet demand of our customers; - the impact of international, national and regional trade laws, regulations and policies; - the uncertainty surrounding Brexit; - the impact of natural disasters, pandemics, terrorism, acts of war, international conflict and political and governmental actions; - our ability to compete in the various markets we serve; - our ability to keep pace with changing technology and manufacturing techniques; - our ability to maintain and enhance our brands; - the use of the “AL-KO” name by other parties or the termination of our trademark license agreement; - the failure to maintain good relationships with our distributors or the actions or inactions of our distributors; - our ability to accurately forecast demand or meet significant increases in demand for our products; - the failure to achieve projected business initiatives in the time periods that we anticipate, or at all; - our dependence on the continued operation of our manufacturing facilities; - the effect of further unionization at our facilities or the impact of work stoppages; iv ----- - our ability to realize all of the anticipated benefits of our acquisitions or divestitures and successfully integrate them into our operations; - our ability to attract, train and retain qualified personnel, including production personnel; - the impact of political, economic and social uncertainty and the continuing and accelerating globalization of businesses; - the impact of security breaches and other disruptions to our information technology infrastructure; - our history of operating losses; - the effect of foreign exchange rates on our financial results; - the impairment of our significant intangible assets; - our ability to satisfy our obligations under our operating leases; - the impact of sustained increases in funding obligations under our pension plans; - changes in tax rates, tax legislation or exposure to additional tax liabilities; - the impact of any losses associated with product liability, recall and warranty claims; - our ability to protect our intellectual property; - the liability associated with the use of products for which patent ownership or other intellectual property rights are claimed; - our ability to comply with various environmental, health and safety laws and regulations and the cost associated with such compliance; - the business and reputational risks related to sustainability and corporate social responsibility; - the impact of any violations of the FCPA; - our ability to comply with governmental laws, regulations and other legal obligations related to privacy and data protection; - the impact on our reputation as a result of improper conduct by any of our employees or business partners; - the risks associated with future acquisitions and new investments; - the effect of covenant restrictions in our debt agreements on our ability to operate our business; and - our ability to service our substantial indebtedness. See “Risk Factors” for a further description of these risks and other factors that could prevent us from achieving our goals, and cause the assumptions underlying forward-looking statements and the actual results to differ materially from those expressed in or implied by those forward-looking statements. v -----

We have included certain supplemental financial measures of our performance in this offering memorandum that have not been calculated in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (“GAAP”), including, for example, Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow. Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow are not prepared with a view towards compliance with published guidelines of the SEC, and are not measures of net income, operating income or any other performance measure derived in accordance with GAAP, and are subject to important limitations. Our use of the terms Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow vary from each other and from others in our industry. For additional information regarding our use of Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow including the reasons that we believe this information is useful to management and to investors, and a reconciliation of Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow to the most closely comparable financial measure calculated in accordance with GAAP, see “Summary—Summary Consolidated Historical Financial and Other Data.” Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow have important limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our financial performance as reported under GAAP and should not be considered as alternatives to net income or any other performance measures derived in accordance with GAAP as measures of operating performance or as alternatives to cash flow from operating activities as measures of our liquidity. This offering memorandum includes certain financial information of Brink International B.V (“Brink”). Brink's financial information was prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards and may not be directly comparable to the same measures prepared in accordance with GAAP.

The information included in this offering memorandum does not conform to information that would be required if this offering were made pursuant to a registration statement filed with the SEC. This offering memorandum, as well as any other documents in connection with this offering, will not be reviewed by the SEC. There are no registration rights associated with the Notes, and we have no intention to offer Notes in a transaction registered under the Securities Act in exchange for the Notes or to file a registration statement with respect to the Notes. The indenture that will govern the Notes will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the “TIA”), or subject to the terms of, or incorporate any provision of, the TIA. We will provide the information required pursuant to Rule 144A(d)(4) upon request.

Some of the market and industry data contained in this offering memorandum are based on independent industry publications or other publicly available information. Although we believe that these independent publications and other publicly available information are reliable as of their respective dates, we have not verified the accuracy or completeness of the data presented from independent sources. In addition, certain market and industry data contained in this offering memorandum are based on internal data, studies and management estimates, which are derived from information obtained from analysts’ reports, independent industry publications or publicly available sources, as well as our clients, partners, trade and business organizations and other contacts in the markets in which we operate, and also reflect our management’s understanding of industry conditions. Although we believe that such information included in this offering memorandum is reliable as of their respective dates, such data, studies and estimates, particularly as they relate to market size, market growth, penetration, market share and our general expectations, involve important risks, uncertainties and assumptions and are subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under “Risk Factors” and “Cautionary Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements” in this offering memorandum. These and other factors could cause results to differ materially from those expressed in the estimates and beliefs made by the independent parties and by us. vi -----

We are a leading global manufacturer and distributor of engineered components critical to the safety and performance of a range of towable and related applications. We deliver exceptional products that our customers rely on. We strive to deliver superior quality, provide the highest level of customer service and offer our customers innovative solutions through customized products and technology. We offer a broad portfolio of axle assemblies, hydraulic components, chassis, aftermarket parts, and other related engineered products. Our manufactured products span over 65,000 SKUs and are sold under a number of well-known, market-leading brands, including our flagship Dexter and AL-KO brands. We offer over 30,000 additional SKUs throughout our distribution network. We serve over 40,000 customers globally. Our manufactured products are used in applications across a diverse set of end-use segments, including agriculture, commercial, construction, general industrial, livestock, landscaping, marine, military, energy, residential, recreational vehicle (“RV”), transportation and many other specialty end-use segments. The majority of our products are critical to the reliability, safety and performance of the end-products in which they are utilized. Given the high cost of downtime relative to the cost of our products, our customers and the ultimate end-users of our products place a premium on the superior performance and reliability our products deliver. Our two flagship brands, Dexter in North America and AL-KO in the rest of the world, account for the majority of our sales. Our other brands, including CM Trailers, Kodiak, Redline, Redneck, Rockwell American, Silent Drive, Aguti, Bankside Patterson, CBE, E&P Hydraulics, Nordelettronica, Safim, Sawiko, G&S Chassis and upon consummation of the acquisition of Brink International B.V., Brink, are also recognized for product quality, reliability, innovation and superior customer service. The foregoing attributes, combined with our ability to deliver customized products with short lead times, have created deep and long-standing relationships with our customers. Our customer base is primarily made up of relatively small companies that lack engineering expertise in our product categories, thus we enjoy an advantaged position within a highly fragmented industry. Our advanced engineering expertise and proximity to our customers deeply ingrain us into our customers’ product design, engineering and development processes, enhance our longterm customer retention and support premium pricing for our products. We operate our business on a regional basis through our two reportable segments, North America and Rest of World (“RoW”). Within the majority of the end-use segments in which we compete, we estimate our sales are approximately five times larger than that of our next largest North American competitor and approximately three times larger than that of our largest European competitor. In addition, we believe that we have the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distributor of light and medium duty components for towable applications in North America. In 2020, 89% of our net sales were in end-use segments where we believe we hold the number one or number two position, based on management’s extensive knowledge and expertise in the industry. We believe that we are the primary axle provider to approximately two-thirds of our customers in North America and we are larger than the majority of our suppliers. Based on management’s knowledge of the industry, we believe that our scale, combined with our vertically integrated hub-and-spoke manufacturing and broad distribution network, enables us to respond to customer requests with premium quality customized product solutions, on shorter delivery lead times than many of our competitors and at an attractive cost position. 1 -----

Industrial and Utility (2) 47% (1) Rest of World 44% Components and other 46% Axle and Chassis 54% North America 56% Other 14% Aftermarket 15% Recreation 24% Note: Business breakdown based on 2020 Net Sales. (1) Rest of World includes Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom, Spain, France, Australia and several other countries. (2) Industrial & Utility includes Agriculture, Commercial, Construction, Do-it-yourself (“DIY”), Energy, Transportation, Military and Specialty Heavy Duty. In January 2021, we acquired Redneck Inc. and Redline Products LLC (together, “Redneck”), a leading distributor of trailer components in North America. Together with our Rockwell American distribution business, this acquisition creates what we believe to be the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distributor of light and medium duty components for towable applications in North America, provides us with unique insights into end-consumer behavior and preferences, and increases our aftermarket net sales. Our strong brand reputation and growing installed base allow us to capture high margin aftermarket business. In 2020, aftermarket net sales as a percentage of consolidated net sales would have increased from 15% to approximately 20% if Redneck sales were included. In July 2021, we reached an agreement to acquire the European towbar solutions specialist Brink International B.V., which expands our portfolio into the area of engineered towing and carrying solutions. Brink enjoys a global manufacturing footprint and long-term exclusive relationships with major OEs, with a strong focus on performance, safety standards, availability and innovation. Approximately 73% of Brink’s 2020 net sales are from retrofit and 27% from line fit. Brink’s difficult to replicate product offerings and large SKU availability drives its leading position in the aftermarket. We believe compelling underlying trends will support future growth with increasing Brink towbar take rates, growing share of SUVs, increased consumer interest in towing products and low towbar share penetration of existing vehicles. We have consistently delivered strong financial and operating results. For the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, we generated net sales of $1,534.0 million and $1,506.6 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $268.5 million and $247.0 million, respectively. For the trailing twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we generated net sales of $2,252.0 million and Leverageable EBITDA of $380.2 million, pro forma for the acquisition of Brink. 2 -----

Industrial and utility 61% Industrial and utility 29% Recreation 37% We have a long history as a manufacturer of components and systems for towable and related applications. DexKo Global Inc. (“DexKo Global”) was formed at the end of 2015 through the combination of two industryleading businesses, Dexter Axle in North America and AL-KO in RoW. Dexter Axle was founded in Elkhart, Indiana by Leonard Dexter in 1960. The product offering was initially limited to manufactured housing and RV axles, but over time, Dexter Axle expanded its portfolio. Dexter Axle underwent a number of ownership changes: it was acquired by Philips Industries, Inc. in 1966, which was later acquired by Tomkins plc, a broad, industrial conglomerate in 1990, and was sold to The Sterling Group, L.P. (“Sterling”) in 2012. AL-KO was founded in Kötz, Germany in 1931 by Alois Kober and grew to become the leading European designer and manufacturer of trailer axles, trailer components, chassis and motorized chassis. In 1988, AL-KO expanded into Australia through the acquisition of Girlock Caravan and Trailer Parts. 3 ----- From 2012 to 2017, Dexter Axle grew its market share by introducing new product lines, entering new enduse segments and executing eight strategic acquisitions, including the acquisition of AL-KO at the end of 2015. In 2015, DexKo established the DexKo Operating System to drive operational improvements, and since then, increased axle production per square foot of manufacturing space by over 25% in the Dexter Axle business. Since 2015, DexKo’s product offering has become significantly more diversified and we have become a true global leader in towable and related applications with a presence across six continents. In July 2017, we were acquired by KPS Capital Partners, LP. Beyond strategic M&A, we have continued to implement the DexKo Operating System and have upgraded key personnel across operations, finance, sales, technology, innovation and M&A. We have focused on continuous improvement initiatives such as labor productivity, SG&A optimization, strategic sourcing and facility consolidations, as well as strategic commercial actions. As a result of these initiatives, we increased our Adjusted EBITDA every year since 2018, despite the impact of COVID-19 on the global economy in 2020. Our leadership team that has supported this transformation is led by Fred Bentley, President and Chief Executive Officer, Matthew W. Hughes, Chief Financial Officer and William Meador II, Chief Operating Officer. All three individuals have long tenures at industry-leading firms, averaging over 25 years of experience. Through their efforts, we have evolved from two strong regional companies into a recognized global leader. In July 2021, Brookfield Business Partners L.P., announced the agreement to acquire DexKo for approximately $3.7 billion, including the estimated total cash consideration of $279.0 million to be paid for the acquisition of Brink. Brookfield and its institutional partners will invest approximately $1.2 billion of equity as part of the funding of the purchase price. We offer our products and services in 91 countries across the globe, with 56% of our 2020 net sales from North America. Outside of North America, we primarily serve developed markets with little dependency on any single geography in Europe (Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom, Spain and France, among others) or Australia. 4 ----- We are well-established in the regions we serve with an emphasis on developed economies. We are strategically positioned to enter new end-use segments and geographic regions as opportunities arise, both organically and through acquisitions. Specifically, our manufacturing footprint is spread across 22 countries and six continents, totaling 50 flexible manufacturing and assembly facilities, with four sub-component manufacturing plants, 23 other product assembly plants and 23 other product manufacturing plants. Our footprint is unique in the industry and enables us to serve our customers on a global scale. Our manufacturing plants are strategically positioned relative to our worldwide distribution footprint so that we can serve our customers reliably and efficiently in every major region with extremely short lead times and on-time delivery rates. Our distribution network includes 50 company-operated distribution locations and over 9,500 individual external distributors across the globe. Subsubsection Text: In 2019, we added a wide range of highly engineered hydraulic components to our product offering through our acquisition of Safim. Safim’s products are critical to the safety and performance of a wide range of customer applications in agriculture, construction, material handling and other diverse end-use segments, and represent an attractive growth platform with significant opportunity for further expansion. We have also added a selection of seat systems, seat-connection systems and accessories adaptable to a wide range of motorhomes, electric and specialty vehicles through our acquisition of Aguti in 2019. Brink._ In July 2021, we reached an agreement to acquire the European towbar solutions specialist Brink International B.V., which will expand our portfolio into the area of engineered towing and carrying solutions, pending the consummation of the Brink acquisition. Brink products include flanged balls, fixed, detachable and retractable towbars with vehicle specific wiring kits. Subsubsection Text: _17,500 – 60,000 lbs._ We continue to grow share and create a first-mover advantage through our extensive new product development process. For example, we created SMART-STEER[™], the only heavy duty self-steering axle that combines unmatched stability, full customization, full braking and load-carrying capability to deliver top performance. These axles can be mounted on several suspension models and tailored to any given application. Many of our torsion axles contain our proprietary TORFLEX[™] system, a torsion arm type suspension which is completely self-contained within the axle tube. _Chassis. We offer integrated and motorized chassis for trailers, light commercial and recreational applications_ that are tailored to our customers’ specifications. Our standard torsion bar suspension is unique among chassis manufacturers in the leisure vehicle market. Our design ensures maximum safety, enhanced driving dynamics, increased payload capacity, energy efficiency and improved driving comfort. 5 ----- Our dedicated team of research and development (“R&D”) engineers has developed highly innovative solutions for customers that are new to the market, such as the lightweight VARIO-X[™] chassis. Additionally, we offer engineering, manufacturing and assembly solutions for electric-powered light commercial and recreational vehicle manufacturers. We are in the process of developing a hybrid power chassis to enable emission-free, allelectric driving in urban environments. _17,500 – 60,000 lbs._ We continue to grow share and create a first-mover advantage through our extensive new product development process. We offer a variety of innovative engineered components, and we are able to provide our customers a high degree of customization in each of these product categories. Our products are critical to safety and performance, but represent only 2% to 15% of the total manufacturing cost of the end product. Further, we believe the cost to the endcustomer of a day of a down trailer or piece of equipment would be significant, thus requiring customers to focus on reliability when making purchasing decisions. We believe that we have the leading products in the majority of our key categories. Furthermore, our products are used in a wide range of applications, significantly reducing our exposure to the demand dynamics of any one end-use segment. Subsection Title: 5-to-10-Day Lead Time for Most Products and Targeted 98% On-time Delivery
Subsubsection Text: Our products are sold through two primary channels, through distributors and direct to customers who manufacture towable and other products with various end-use applications. Our distribution network includes 50 company-operated distribution locations and over 9,500 individual external distributors across the globe and enables us to serve smaller customers efficiently. With our diversified base of over 40,000 customers globally across 91 countries, we maintain a low customer concentration with our largest customer representing approximately 10% of fiscal year 2020 net sales and our top ten customers accounting for approximately 30% of total fiscal year 2020 net sales. We have long-term customer relationships, many spanning over 25 years. 8 Neuenkirchen, Germany Winchester, TN Atlanta, GA Sura Mica, Romania Ettenbeuren, Germany Paderborn, Germany Fremont, IN Moscow, R Paderborn, Germany Ettenbeuren, Germany Verona, Italy Royse City, TX El Reno, OK Ramsau, Austria Zaragoza, Spain Winchester, TN Monticello, GA Royse City, TX Kötz, Germany Plant City, FL Louhans, France Yantai, China Ramsau, Austria Verona, Italy El Reno, OK Fremont, IN Atlanta, GA Elkhart, IN ----- Our critical role in the value chain has created an opportunity for greater collaboration with our customers. Since our production facilities are strategically located near our customers, we are able to swiftly respond to their product configuration requests. We are typically able to respond to customer requests in less than two weeks, which we believe, based on our management’s knowledge of the industry, represents an industry-leading lead time. Our distribution network ensures the availability of our products, enabling our customers to optimize their inventory management. Our unique position within the distribution network enhances long-term customer retention and supports premium pricing for our products. In January 2021, we significantly expanded our North American distribution network through our acquisition of Redneck, a leading distributor of trailer components in North America. Redneck distributes a deep catalogue of stocked trailer parts and accessories to thousands of manufacturers, dealers, and retail customers. This acquisition positions us closer to our customers, which provides valuable insights into end-consumer behavior and preferences and materially increases our aftermarket sales. Together with our Rockwell American business, we believe that we have the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distribution network of components for towable applications in North America. Our leading distribution network further improves our ability to maintain what we believe are best-in-class lead times and customer service, strengthens our connectivity with end-users and allows us to directly supply our products to a broad customer base. Our products are sold through two primary channels, through distributors and direct to customers who manufacture towable and other products with various end-use applications. Our distribution network includes 50 company-operated distribution locations and over 9,500 individual external distributors across the globe and enables us to serve smaller customers efficiently. With our diversified base of over 40,000 customers globally across 91 countries, we maintain a low customer concentration with our largest customer representing approximately 10% of fiscal year 2020 net sales and our top ten customers accounting for approximately 30% of total fiscal year 2020 net sales. We have long-term customer relationships, many spanning over 25 years. Our critical role in the value chain has created an opportunity for greater collaboration with our customers. Since our production facilities are strategically located near our customers, we are able to swiftly respond to their product configuration requests. We are typically able to respond to customer requests in less than two weeks, which we believe, based on our management’s knowledge of the industry, represents an industry-leading lead time. Our distribution network ensures the availability of our products, enabling our customers to optimize their inventory management. Our unique position within the distribution network enhances long-term customer retention and supports premium pricing for our products. In January 2021, we significantly expanded our North American distribution network through our acquisition of Redneck, a leading distributor of trailer components in North America. Redneck distributes a deep catalogue of stocked trailer parts and accessories to thousands of manufacturers, dealers, and retail customers. This acquisition positions us closer to our customers, which provides valuable insights into end-consumer behavior and preferences and materially increases our aftermarket sales. Together with our Rockwell American business, we believe that we have the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distribution network of components for towable applications in North America. Our leading distribution network further improves our ability to maintain what we believe are best-in-class lead times and customer service, strengthens our connectivity with end-users and allows us to directly supply our products to a broad customer base. 99 -----

Subsection Title: 5-to-10-Day Lead Time for Most Products and Targeted 98% On-time Delivery
5-to-10-Day Lead Time for Most Products and Targeted 98% On-time Delivery
Subsubsection Text: Moscow, R Southam, UK Neuenkirchen, Germany Albion, IN Paderborn, Germany Fremont, IN Ettenbeuren, Germany Kötz, Germany San Marcos, CA El Reno, OK Ramsau, Austria Elkhart, IN Winchester, TN Louhans, France Atlanta, GA Shawnee, OK Sura Mica, Romania Monticello, GA Royse City, TX Zaragoza, Spain Verona, Italy Plant City, FL Atibaia, Brazil Vereeniging, South Africa Manufacturing “Hubs” Melbourne, Australia Assembly “Spokes” Our operations have grown to 50 flexible manufacturing and assembly facilities with over four million square feet of manufacturing space. Our four strategically located, centralized sub-component manufacturing plants (“hubs”) provide an optimized distribution framework that is core to our hub-and-spoke business model. Our manufacturing hubs are located in Albion, Indiana; Kötz, Germany; Ramsau, Austria; and Yantai, China. These plants manufacture and distribute critical sub-components, such as stampings, axle spindles, brake magnets, brake linings, brake assemblies, hubs, drums and suspension components, which are then sent to our 23 product assembly plants (“spokes”) across North America and Europe. The “spokes” assemble the sub-components from the “hubs” into a finished product, establishing a key element of our best-in-class cost structure. This model enables us to scale production rapidly and respond to customer requests with extremely short lead times, thus significantly reducing our customers’ working capital needs, because our “hubs” are in the same geography as the “spokes” and we do not rely on purchasing value-add components from any one supplier. In addition to our four “hubs” and 23 product assembly plants, we also operate 23 plants that manufacture other product offerings. We offer best-in-class five to ten day lead times for most products with targeted 98% on-time delivery. We manage our input costs through strategic sourcing and procurement initiatives, including sourcing locally, which allows us to leverage our purchasing power. Our strategy enables us to mitigate our exposure to regional trade disputes, tariffs and inflationary headwinds. The proximity of our facilities to our customers and our world-class distribution network enable us to provide customized product solutions and significantly reduce delivery lead times, and we believe they increase our customers’ reliance upon us. Our efficient manufacturing and assembly business model enables us to rapidly adjust our operations in response to changing demand trends and provide an unmatched level of customer service. 7 ----- Our vertically integrated hub-and-spoke manufacturing and distribution model is core to our global operations. Section Title: OUR DIVERSE END-USE SEGMENTS AND COMPETITIVE LANDSCAPE
Subsubsection Text: Our industry is highly fragmented with the majority of our competitors lacking significant scale, which results in regionally focused competition based on where our competitors primarily operate. Within the majority of the enduse segments in which we compete, we estimate our sales are approximately five times larger than that of our next largest North American competitor and approximately three times larger than that of our largest European competitor. In addition, we believe that we have the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distributor of light and medium duty components for towable applications in North America. In 2020, 89% of our 10 ----- net sales were in end-use segments where we believe we hold the number one or number two position, based on management’s extensive knowledge and expertise in the industry. Competition within our industry is driven by our customers’ focus on product quality, lead times and price. Customers value reliability and quality and are willing to pay a premium to source high-performance components on a short lead time basis. The majority of our products are critical to safety and performance but comprise a small portion of the overall cost of the equipment in which they are used, typically 2% to 15% of the total manufacturing cost of the end product. As such, customers are more likely to pay for higher-quality components without meaningfully shifting their overall cost structure. We are well positioned with our competitive strengths to fulfill our customers’ requirements for premium products and services. Subsection Title: Diverse Customer Base <1% of DexKo’s Customers Have More than $250m in Annual Revenue
Subsubsection Title: Vertically integrated hub-and-spoke model leads to enhanced customization and customer-centric approach supported by industry-leading distribution network
Subsubsection Text: Our vertically integrated hub-and-spoke manufacturing, assembly, and distribution model allows us to respond to customer requests with extremely short lead times. We have centralized sub-component manufacturing and thousands of distribution points close to our customers worldwide. With four sub-component manufacturing “hubs”, 23 product assembly “spokes” and 50 company-operated distribution locations, which give us unique insight into buyer behavior and preferences, we are able to service demand globally and support our customers with just-in-time inventory management. In addition, we also operate 23 plants that manufacture other product offerings. Our demonstrated scale, proximity to our customers and vertical integration, positions us as a trusted supply chain partner. The vertically integrated nature of our manufacturing footprint provides flexibility for us to engineer, design and produce key sub-components internally at a lower cost than sourcing externally. With the optionality to manufacture critical systems in-house, we are able to have significant control over our supply chain. Our centralized sub-component manufacturing plants feed inputs to product assembly plants, allowing efficient servicing of demand at what we believe are 10% to 15% lower production costs than competitors, and results in what we believe are shorter lead times than competitors that have to source from third-party suppliers. Furthermore, our manufacturing footprint has a highly flexible cost structure, as approximately 80% of our cash costs are variable. Our distribution network provides optimized access to smaller original equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”) and close proximity to customers. Historically, we have been able to deliver most of our products within five to ten days, less than half of the industry standard, with a targeted on-time delivery of 98% despite a high degree of product complexity and customization. Additionally, we are able to maintain these short lead times despite typically 12 ----- producing in small batches. For example, the typical order size in our largest assembly plant, Fremont, Indiana, is approximately nine axles compared to over 480,000 axles assembled annually in that plant. We believe this capability is unique within our industry. Our distribution network was further strengthened by the acquisition of Redneck in January 2021. Through this acquisition, DexKo has created what it believes to be the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distribution network of components for towable applications in North America. We have doubled our North American distribution footprint and expanded and diversified our customer base. Subsection Title: Diverse Customer Base <1% of DexKo’s Customers Have More than $250m in Annual Revenue
Subsubsection Title: Well-positioned to take advantage of attractive industry dynamics and growing end-use segments
Subsubsection Text: We serve a wide range of end-use segments, including agriculture, commercial, construction, general industrial, livestock, landscaping, marine, military, energy, residential, RV and many other specialty end-use segments. We see a strong growth outlook across our key-end use segments, complemented by durable tailwinds in the popularity of outdoor activities and lifestyle trends. We expect inventory restocking to further drive near-term demand and see infrastructure spending momentum to provide tailwinds for non-residential construction and broader economic activity. We believe these industry dynamics and the growth outlook in key end-use segments bode well for DexKo, and will drive increased demand for its products. The North American axle market is expected to show robust growth driven by high expected demand from RVs followed by industrial / utility and marine segments. European axle and chassis demand is also expected to show strong growth driven by high expected demand in motorhomes and light commercial trailers. We serve a wide range of end-use segments, including agriculture, commercial, construction, general industrial, livestock, landscaping, marine, military, energy, residential, RV and many other specialty end-use segments. We expect inventory restocking to further drive near-term demand and see infrastructure spending momentum to provide tailwinds for non-residential construction and broader economic activity. We believe these industry dynamics and the growth outlook in key end-use segments bode well for DexKo, and will drive increased demand for its products. European axle and chassis demand is also expected to show strong growth driven by high expected demand in motorhomes and light commercial trailers.

Subsection Title: Diverse Customer Base <1% of DexKo’s Customers Have More than $250m in Annual Revenue
Subsubsection Title: Cycle resiliency driven by diversification, flexible cost structure and replacement demand
Subsubsection Text: DexKo has shown strong resilience through prior economic downturns. We have maintained North American net sales and Adjusted EBITDA through industrial slow-downs and our RoW business has had minimal impact during slower GDP periods. Furthermore, our strong 2020 financial performance, despite COVID-19-related challenges, demonstrates our highly diversified end-use segments, our highly variable cost structure and our ability 13 ----- to swiftly adapt to changes in demand, leveraging both our vertically integrated hub-and-spoke model and unmatched distribution network. A key driver of this resiliency is that approximately 85% of our revenue is driven by an 8-10 year replacement cycle of commercial and industrial trailers. Rugged and harsh environment applications and relatively low replacement cost drives the trailer replacement cycle, since it is typically more economical to replace the full trailer as opposed to individual components at the end of the useful life. Approximately 15% of our net sales in 2020 was represented by aftermarket sales (excluding Redneck). With the inclusion of Redneck, the share of aftermarket sales would have been approximately 20%. This creates a stable recurring revenue base, which is further supported by our large installed base of approximately 40 million Dexter axles and 12 million AL-KO products, driving stability and consistency in our revenues. DexKo is well established in key developed markets which drive stable growth, and well positioned for future growth in emerging markets. Our products are sold into a very diverse set of end-use segments and are used in a wide range of applications, which serve to offset the impact of any one end-use segment trend and provide stability for our business. We sell products in 91 countries across six continents, with 44% of our 2020 sales outside of North America. Our geographic diversity, low customer concentration and broad product offering, together with a relatively low average order size of approximately $6,300, provides a balanced and diverse revenue base and stability throughout the various demand trends of our end-use segments. We serve over 40,000 customers globally, ranging from well-established blue-chip customers to smaller regional and local customers. For the majority of our customers we are the sole source supplier for the engineered components we manufacture. We have relationships with many of our customers that exceed 25 years, and an approximately 98% retention rate with all of our customers. We have customer facing personnel at our plants and headquarters, plus dedicated sales professionals providing global coverage. We further support our customers with comprehensive warranty terms, which we believe strengthens customer loyalty. We continuously strengthen our long-term relationships through frequent collaboration with our customers to develop solutions meeting specific engineering requirements. Our customer base is comprised primarily of small customers, most of which do not maintain an independent product development or engineering team focused on our products. We are ingrained in our customers’ product development process and our ability to support their supply chain by delivering highly customized, small batches with short lead times is core to the longevity of our relationships. We believe our customer relationships position us for ongoing replacement business. We have a highly flexible cost structure with 80% of our costs being variable and we have low maintenance capex requirements. This allows us to flex our capacity to meet changing market demand dynamics. Furthermore, we have limited supplier concentration, which enables us to effectively manage changing input costs and diversifies our exposure away from any one supplier. Subsection Title: Diverse Customer Base <1% of DexKo’s Customers Have More than $250m in Annual Revenue
Subsubsection Title: Exceptional financial track record with strong free cash flow generation
Subsubsection Text: We have a highly attractive financial profile that has delivered strong organic and inorganic growth and expanded margins. We operate in markets with strong near and long term growth trends. We have generated total net sales growth averaging 11% for the five years ended December 31, 2020 and have generated Adjusted EBITDA growth averaging greater than 15% over the same period. In addition, we have generated historical organic net sales and Adjusted EBITDA growth averaging greater than 3% and 9%, respectively, over the five years ended December 31, 2020, despite the impact of COVID-19. We expect to continue to grow in excess of GDP in the regions we serve. We have expanded Adjusted EBITDA margins from 15.8% in 2016 to 17.5% in 2020. Given our low capital expenditure, which averaged 2.6% of net sales from 2016 to 2020, we have a very strong cash flow conversion – our realized FCF conversion[(1)] was 86% in 2020. We plan to continue to use our strong and stable cash flows to continue to reduce our indebtedness, deploy our capital to drive organic growth, innovate and pursue M&A opportunities. (1) Our historical FCF conversion is calculated as (Adjusted EBITDA – Capex) / Adjusted EBITDA 14 ----- We have a highly attractive financial profile that has delivered strong organic and inorganic growth and expanded margins. We operate in markets with strong near and long term growth trends. We have generated total net sales growth averaging 11% for the five years ended December 31, 2020 and have generated Adjusted EBITDA growth averaging greater than 15% over the same period. In addition, we have generated historical organic net sales and Adjusted EBITDA growth averaging greater than 3% and 9%, respectively, over the five years ended December 31, 2020, despite the impact of COVID-19. We expect to continue to grow in excess of GDP in the regions we serve. We have expanded Adjusted EBITDA margins from 15.8% in 2016 to 17.5% in 2020. Given our low capital expenditure, which averaged 2.6% of net sales from 2016 to 2020, we have a very strong cash flow conversion – our realized FCF conversion[(1)] was 86% in 2020. We plan to continue to use our strong and stable cash flows to continue to reduce our indebtedness, deploy our capital to drive organic growth, innovate and pursue M&A opportunities. Subsection Title: Diverse Customer Base <1% of DexKo’s Customers Have More than $250m in Annual Revenue
Subsubsection Text: Our management team is comprised of highly experienced individuals, each with long tenures at leading large, world-class industrial companies. Our executive leadership team is led by Fred Bentley, who formerly served as the Chief Executive Officer of Maxion Wheels and held management positions overseeing operations at Honeywell and Frito Lay. Matthew W. Hughes, our Chief Financial Officer, has held numerous segment Chief Financial Officer and executive roles at well-established firms, such as International Game Technology PLC, a global leader in the gaming industry, and Nortek Holdings Inc. William Meador II, our Chief Operating Officer, formerly served as SVP North America at Haldex Brake Products Inc. and Chief Executive Officer of Motor Wheel CVS. With an average tenure of over 25 years of operational, financial and managerial experience, the DexKo management team has transformed two leading yet regionally focused companies into a global, fully integrated professional organization. Our management team is highly focused on fostering a culture of operational excellence, leading to a track record of robust organic growth, margin expansion and accretive M&A. We implemented the DexKo Operating System to drive internal initiatives such as pricing discipline, headcount rationalization, facility consolidation, global procurement, efficiency improvements and portfolio management, including exiting non-core businesses. Restructuring activities executed since the Company was formed in 2015 have added approximately $33 million in annual savings to our calculation of Adjusted EBITDA. Our management team’s strong leadership has led to increases in our Adjusted EBITDA every year since DexKo’s formation. We expect further margin enhancement through a number of ongoing initiatives and focus on continuous improvement. We have also made attracting bestin-class talent a top priority for our organization, and have upgraded key personnel across finance, sales, operations, innovation and M&A. Subsubsection Text: Our manufactured product offering, with over 65,000 SKUs, is the most expansive portfolio of engineered components for our customers’ applications. Our specialized workforce of over 190 engineers uniquely positions us to design and manufacture specialized, custom solutions to meet our customers’ exact specifications. We believe our product breadth and ability to offer custom solutions enables our customers to make efficient purchasing decisions and reinforces the brand and customer loyalty we have earned throughout our history. Our ability to deliver a broad range of customized products with extremely short lead times creates a “one-stop-shop” value proposition to our customers. We attribute our success and historical performance to the following key strengths that differentiate us from our competition: We attribute our success and historical performance to the following key strengths that differentiate us from our competition:

On July 3, 2021, Parent and Merger Sub, entities controlled by investment funds managed by Brookfield Capital Partners LLC ( “BCP”), entered into the Merger Agreement (which was subsequently amended on July 29, 2021) with the Company and the Equityholder Representative, pursuant to which Parent agreed to acquire the Company by effecting a merger of Merger Sub with and into the Company, with the Company as the surviving entity. Upon the closing of the Acquisition, Parent will pay approximately $3.7 billion in cash, in the aggregate, to acquire the Company, including the estimated total cash consideration of $279.0 million to be paid for the acquisition of Brink, subject to certain adjustments. Completion of the Acquisition is subject to various conditions, including, among others, (i) approvals and/or termination or expiration of any applicable waiting periods (including any extensions thereof) under the HSR Act and under certain foreign antitrust laws or foreign direct investment laws, including the European Union, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, Brazil, France and Spain (ii) the absence of any order, or the enactment of any law, following the execution of the Merger Agreement prohibiting the Acquisition, (iii) subject to certain exceptions, the accuracy of the representations and warranties of the parties contained in the Merger Agreement and (iv) performance in all material respects by each party of its obligations under the Merger Agreement. The Merger Agreement contains customary representations, warranties and covenants of the parties thereto, including, among others, covenants (i) of the Company to use commercially reasonable efforts to, and cause its subsidiaries to use commercially reasonable efforts to, conduct their business and operations in the ordinary course in all material respects during the interim period between the execution of the Merger Agreement and completion of the Acquisition, (ii) of the Company not to engage in certain transactions during the interim period except with Parent’s written consent and (iii) of the parties to execute such documents and perform such further acts as may be reasonably required to carry out the provisions of the Merger Agreement and the actions contemplated thereby and use their reasonable best efforts to fulfill or obtain the fulfillment of the conditions precedent to consummate the transactions contemplated by the Merger Agreement. The Merger Agreement also contains certain termination rights for both the Company and Parent, including the right of either party to terminate the Merger Agreement if, other than in certain circumstances described therein, the Merger has not been consummated by April 15, 2022 and certain other conditions specified under the Merger Agreement are met. The Merger Agreement provides that, if any party to the Merger Agreement fails or refuses to perform any covenant or agreement, the non-breaching party will be entitled to specific performance of such covenant or agreement, subject to certain restrictions on the ability of the Company to seek specific performance to cause Parent and Merger Sub to draw down the equity financing. In addition, upon termination of the Merger Agreement under specified circumstances, Parent may be required to pay the Company a termination fee.

To finance the Acquisition and related refinancing transactions, we intend to issue the Notes offered hereby and, concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition, enter into (i) new senior secured credit facilities (the “New Senior Secured Credit Facilities”), initially consisting of (x) a 7-year $2,210.0 million equivalent principal amount first lien term loan facility (the “New Term Loan Facility”) consisting of (1) a $800.0 million US Dollar denominated tranche (the “Initial New USD Term Loan”), (2) a $1,130.0 million Euro equivalent Euro denominated tranche (the “Initial New Euro Term Loan” and, together with the Initial New USD Term Loan, the “Initial New Term Loan Facility”), (3) a $160.0 million US Dollar denominated delayed draw tranche (the “Delayed Draw USD Term Loan” and, together with the Initial New USD Term Loan, the “New USD Term Loan”) and (4) a $120.0 million Euro equivalent Euro denominated delayed draw tranche (the “Delayed Draw Euro Term Loan” and, together with the Initial New Euro Term Loan, the “New Euro Term Loan”; the Delayed Draw Euro Term Loan and the Delayed Draw USD Term Loan are referred to herein as the “Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility”) and (y) a 5-year $200 million first lien revolving credit facility (the “New Revolving Facility”) and (ii) a new 5-year $150 million asset-based revolving credit facility (the “New ABL Facility”). We intend to use the proceeds of this offering and the borrowings under the Initial New Term Loan Facility, together with equity contributions from funds affiliated 17 ----- with BCP and other investors (or limited partners of funds associated with either thereof), to (1) pay the cash consideration for the Acquisition and (2) pay related fees and expenses. The foregoing financing transactions described in this paragraph are collectively referred to in this offering memorandum as the “Acquisition Financing Transactions.” The Acquisition, the Acquisition Financing Transactions and the payment of related fees and expenses are collectively referred to in this offering memorandum as the “Transactions.” The closing of this offering is not conditioned on consummation of the other Acquisition Financing Transactions, but release of the proceeds of this offering from the escrow account (as described below) will require, among other things, that the borrowings under the Initial New Term Loan Facility be drawn in connection with the Acquisition and be available to the Issuer on the date of such release. We cannot assure you that such Acquisition Financing Transactions will be completed or, if completed, on what terms they will be completed.

On July 16, 2021, we entered into a purchase agreement to acquire Brink for €235 million, subject to customary closing adjustments, a leading provider of towing and carrying solutions in Europe headquartered in Staphorst, Netherlands and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 had sales of approximately $187 million and Adjusted EBITDA of approximately $33 million. Our acquisition of Brink is subject to customary closing conditions. All regulatory approvals in connection with our acquisition of Brink have been received, and the Brink acquisition is expected to close on September 30, 2021. The Acquisition is not conditioned on the acquisition of Brink and the Brink acquisition may close after the Acquisition.

Participating in this offering involves substantial risk. Our ability to execute our strategy also is subject to certain risks. The risks described under the heading “Risk Factors” immediately following this summary may cause 19 ----- us not to realize the full benefits of our competitive strengths or may cause us to be unable to successfully execute all or part of our strategy. Some of the more significant challenges and risks we face include the following: - the financial stability of our customers, some of whom serve cyclical industries, could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition; - the financial stability of our suppliers and the ability of our suppliers to produce quality materials could adversely affect our ability to obtain timely and cost-effective raw materials and other inputs used in the manufacturing process; - our business faces competition in all areas, and if we are unable to compete successfully, we may lose market share and sales; - the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic (“COVID-19”) on our business operations and financial stability; - our products are typically highly engineered or customer-driven and we are subject to risks associated with changing technology and manufacturing techniques that could place us at a competitive disadvantage; - our business depends on our strong brands, and if we are not able to maintain and enhance our brands we may be unable to sell our products; - our business depends on maintaining good relationships with our distributors, and if we are not able to maintain good relations, the actions or inactions of our distributors could have an adverse effect on our results of operations and ability to generate cash flow; - our long-term growth strategy includes acquisitions and divestitures and we may not realize all of the anticipated benefits, these benefits may take longer to realize than expected or we may experience difficulty in integrating acquired businesses; - our business is largely dependent on our ability to attract, train and retain qualified personnel, and if we lose the services of any such employees, it may disrupt our operations and have an adverse effect on our business; - our business has a history of operating losses and may not achieve or maintain profitability in the future; and - our substantial indebtedness could adversely affect our ability to raise additional capital or to fund our operations, expose us to interest rate risk to the extent of our variable rate debt, limit our ability to react to changes in the economy, and prevent us from making debt service payments. See “Risk Factors” immediately following this summary for a more thorough discussion of these and other risks and uncertainties we face. 20 -----

We may draw delayed draw term loans to finance a purchase price increase of the Acquisition as a result of one or more acquisitions or similar transactions by the Company, or to refinance indebtedness incurred by the Company to finance any such acquisitions or similar transactions, in each case if after giving effect to the Acquisition and the incurrence of such delayed draw term loans and other indebtedness on the closing date of the Acquisition, the pro forma first lien net leverage ratio does not exceed 5.00:1.00 and the pro forma total net leverage ratio does not exceed 6.75:1.00. As of and for the six months ended June 30, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020, before intercompany eliminations, our non-guarantor subsidiaries represented approximately 33.2% and 33.0% of our revenues, 32.1% and 27.4% of our Adjusted EBITDA and 22.1% and 22.2% of our total assets (excluding cash), respectively. (7) From and after the Escrow Release Date, the Notes will be jointly and severally, unconditionally guaranteed by Holdings and each of the Issuer’s existing and future wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries that guarantee the Issuer’s obligations under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New ABL Facility. At the closing of the Acquisition, the Notes will be (i) effectively subordinated to the Issuer’s and the guarantors’ secured indebtedness under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New ABL Facility to the extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness and (ii) structurally subordinated to the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New ABL Facility to the extent of the obligations of the foreign subsidiaries of the Issuer that guarantee such indebtedness but do not guarantee the Notes.

Certain entities affiliated with Brookfield Asset Management Inc. (“Brookfield”), will own all of the equity interests of the Company together with its affiliates upon the consummation of the Acquisition. Brookfield is a leading global alternative asset manager with a 120-year history and operations across a broad portfolio of real estate, infrastructure, renewable power, private equity and credit assets. With assets under management of over $600.0 billion, its investments include one of the largest portfolios of office properties in the world, an industryleading infrastructure business spanning utilities, transport, energy, communications infrastructure and sustainable resources, and one of the largest pure-play renewable power businesses that include approximately 220 hydroelectric facilities as well as several high quality business services and industrial companies. These businesses form the backbone of the global economy, supporting the endeavors of individuals, corporations and governments worldwide. As a global firm, Brookfield supports the employment of approximately 150,000 people in more than 30 countries while working to create strong, profitable businesses. As these businesses grow, Brookfield commits to best-in-class corporate social responsibility practices, mindful of the important role they play in fostering long-term value creation. Brookfield has an excellent track record of demonstrated operational excellence with its portfolio companies and over-achievement with transformational initiatives in previous large-cap industrial transactions. Brookfield was able to leverage the broad and deep expertise of its entire platform to turn around its portfolio companies including GrafTech International, Longview Fibre Co and Westinghouse Electric Co. 22 -----

Subsection Title: Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Data
Subsubsection Text: The following table summarizes the consolidated financial and other data of the Company for the periods and at the dates indicated. We derived the consolidated statements of operations data for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 and the summary consolidated balance sheet data as of December 31, 2020 and 2019 from our audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. We derived the consolidated statements of operations data for the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 and the summary consolidated balance sheet data as of June 30, 2021 from our unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Our historical results are not necessarily indicative of the results that should be expected in any future period. Our audited consolidated financial statements and unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum do not reflect the impact of the Transactions. The unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements of DexKo Global Holdings Inc. have been prepared on the same basis as the audited consolidated financial statements of DexKo Global Holdings Inc. and, in the opinion of management, include all adjustments, consisting of normal recurring adjustments, necessary for a fair statement of the results for those periods. Results for the six-month period ended June 30, 2021 are not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for the full year or any future reporting period. The following tables also set forth certain summary unaudited pro forma financial information as of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021. The pro forma adjustments to the consolidated pro forma financial data of the Company are based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable. Further, the pro forma adjustments are based upon items that are (i) directly attributable to the Transactions, (ii) factually supportable and (iii) with respect to the Unaudited Pro Forma Consolidated Statement of Operations, expected to have a continuing impact on the consolidated results. The summary consolidated pro forma financial information is presented for informational purposes only and does not purport to represent what our financial condition or results of operations actually would have been had the referenced events occurred on the dates indicated or to project our financial condition or results of operations as of any future date or for any future period. In addition, the pro forma net financing charges for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 presented below were calculated using a weightedaverage estimated blended rate of 4.92%. For additional information, see “Unaudited Pro Forma Consolidated Financial Information.” The following information should be read together with the information under the headings “Capitalization,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and “Unaudited Pro Forma Consolidated Financial Information” and the consolidated financial statements of the Company and related notes included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

See “Unaudited Pro Forma Consolidated Financial Information” and “Use of Proceeds.” (2) To provide investors with additional information in connection with our results as determined by GAAP, we disclose Leverageable EBITDA as a non-GAAP measures which management believes provide useful information to investors. Leverageable EBITDA is not calculated in accordance with GAAP and should not be considered as a substitute for net income or any other operating performance measure calculated in accordance with GAAP, and may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies. We use Leverageable EBITDA to measure liquidity and the performance of our business. EBITDA is defined as net income (loss) before income tax expense (benefit), interest expense, net and depreciation and amortization. We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA adjusted for, among other things, (i) 30 ----- (gain) loss on foreign currency related to intercompany loans and foreign currency derivatives, (ii) restructuring expenses, (iii) share-based compensation, (iv) business optimization expenses, (v) sponsor management fees and (vi) acquisition and purchase accounting related items. Leverageable EBITDA is defined as Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to exclude certain items which we believe are not reflective of ongoing performance. We believe that the presentation of Leverageable EBITDA is appropriate to provide additional information to investors about certain material non-cash items that we do not expect to continue at the same level in the future, as well as other items we do not consider indicative of our ongoing operating performance. Further, we believe Leverageable EBITDA provides a meaningful measure of operating profitability because we use it for evaluating our business performance, liquidity and in evaluating potential acquisitions. Leverageable EBITDA is also calculated in a manner consistent with the terms of the instruments that will govern our indebtedness. There are material limitations to using Leverageable EBITDA. Leverageable EBITDA does not take into account certain significant items, including (i) significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments, on our debt, (ii) cash requirements for replacing assets, (iii) tax expense or the cash requirements to pay our taxes, (iv) cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures and (v) all GAAP non-cash and non-recurring adjustments. These limitations are best addressed by considering the economic effects of the excluded items independently, and by considering Leverageable EBITDA in conjunction with net income as calculated in accordance with GAAP. The following table presents a reconciliation from net income (loss), the most directly comparable GAAP measure, to Adjusted EBITDA and from Adjusted EBITDA to Leverageable EBITDA for the periods indicated:
