We employ a dedicated sales force in each of our primary channels. In serving our customers globally, we rely upon our strong historical customer relationships, custom engineering capability, brand recognition, broad product offerings, our established distribution network and varied marketing strategies to bolster sales of our diverse product lines. Our footprint is strategically positioned to service customers on six continents. We have customer facing personnel at our production plants and at our headquarters as well as dedicated sales professionals providing global coverage. These representatives possess local knowledge of product and application requirements, allowing us to meet our customers’ product availability requirements with short lead times.

Subsection Title: Patents, Trademarks and Other Intellectual Property
Subsubsection Text: We maintain and have pending various U.S. and foreign patents, trademarks and other rights to intellectual property relating to our business, which we believe are appropriate to protect our interest in existing products and brands, new inventions, manufacturing processes and product developments. Although our patented technologies and strong brands are important assets and we take measures we believe are appropriate to protect them in the jurisdictions in which we do business, we do not believe that any single patent or trademark is material to our business nor would expiration or invalidity of any patent or trademark have a material adverse effect on our business or our ability to compete. 107 ----- For risks relating to our intellectual property and brands please see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business—We may be unable to adequately protect our intellectual property.” “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business—Our business depends on our strong brands. If we are not able to maintain and enhance our brands, we may be unable to sell our products.” “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business—We do not own the trademark to the “AL-KO” name, but we may use it pursuant to a trademark license entered into in connection with our 2015 acquisition of AL-KO. Use of the “AL-KO” name by other parties or the termination of our trademark license agreement may harm our business.”

Our manufacturing operations are subject to a variety of federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations covering environmental, health and safety matters. Applicable laws and regulations include those governing, among other things, climate change, emissions to air, product stewardship and safety, discharges to water and discharges of wastewater, noise and the generation, handling, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of chemicals and hazardous material and employee safety. We routinely incur costs in order to comply with these laws and regulations. Some of our operations require environmental permits and controls to prevent and reduce air and water pollution. These permits are subject to modification, renewal and revocation by issuing authorities. We own, lease or operate numerous properties (many of which are sites of long-standing manufacturing operations), have been in business for many years and have acquired and disposed of properties and businesses over that time. Under some environmental laws, including the U.S. Superfund law and state law equivalents, liability for the entire cost of the cleanup of contaminated sites may be imposed jointly and severally upon current or former owners, lessees or operators of a facility, or upon any party who sent waste to a disposal site, regardless of fault or the lawfulness of the activities giving rise to the contamination. We are conducting environmental evaluation and clean-up of a limited number of sites. These matters have not had a material adverse effect on our consolidated financial position, results of operations, cash flows or competitive position. Many of our products are used on vehicles and trailers for on-highway use and may be subject to various federal, state and international laws, rules and regulations related to vehicle safety and compliance with road regulations, including those of the U.S. National Highway Transportation Safety Administration and other similar regulatory agencies in the various countries in which our products are used. In addition, certain of our products are subject to homologation and certification requirements by a variety of regulatory bodies, particularly in Europe. Our products are also subject to various laws and regulations relating to, among other things, labeling, storage, transport, and marketing. As a multinational business, are also subject to laws relating to the import and export of our products or components thereof as well as a variety of laws relating to the collection, storage and management of personal information, including the General Data Privacy Regulation in the European Union and similar regulations in other countries. We do not expect that costs related to on-going compliance activities or any potential expenses or liabilities for non-compliance will have a material adverse effect on our consolidated financial position, results of operations, cash flows or competitive position.

As of June 30, 2021, we employed approximately 7,000 full-time employees worldwide, including 3,700 in North America, 2,600 in Europe and 250 in Australia and New Zealand. We employed roughly 30 people in our corporate headquarters. As of June 30, 2021, approximately 11% of our employees in North America were employed under collective bargaining agreements with industrial trade unions and approximately 67% of our employees in Rest of World were employed under international unions or workers’ councils. We believe our relationship with our employees, including those represented by trade unions and workers’ councils, is in good standing. The health and safety of our employees is paramount at DexKo. Safety is a critical metric by which we evaluate our performance as a company and which we report to our Board of Directors monthly and as the first item of business at each board meeting. Our executive leadership team demonstrates its commitment to safety by actively participating in a variety of safety initiatives throughout the Company. Our goal is always to achieve zero recordable injuries in all of our facilities and we have continued to make significant progress toward this goal. We use proven 108 ----- tools and systems to identify safety hazards and mitigate risks. We emphasize learning from past incidents or near misses and we actively share safety information across our facilities on a regular basis. We continuously review and improve our safety programs and training. We require that all incidents be reported, recorded and investigated in order to identify the root cause and allow us to take corrective action and implement preventative measures across the organization. As of June 30, 2021, 55 of our facilities achieved our goal of zero recordable injuries. COVID-19 has presented new health and safety challenges. We responded to the challenge by developing playbooks of additional health and safety measures appropriate for the various types of facilities we operate and the countries in which we have locations. These measures included work-from-home programs where possible, shift realignments, social distancing, mask requirements, additional wash stations, temperature checks prior to entering plant facilities, daily health questionnaires, contact tracing and random COVID testing. These playbooks continue to evolve and we continue to communicate the importance of working in a safe manner to our employees on a daily basis. Enabling each employee to realize his or her maximum potential is another key priority at DexKo. We value diversity and encourage a culture that respects and values the unique attributes, ideas, perspectives, and experiences of each of our employees. We believe that in a global marketplace, a more inclusive and diverse workforce allows us to achieve better results and makes us a stronger business, and we seek to hire and develop diverse candidates and employees and to reinforce an inclusive culture through ongoing training and engagement activities. We have a number of programs to identify and develop our talent, beginning with the search and hiring process, through on-boarding and on-going career development. We focus both on annual goal planning and performance management as well long-term career growth and succession planning. We offer our employees a variety of programs designed to identify professional motivations, potential career interests, current strengths and key growth opportunities, and to identify and track targeted development activities and progress. We seek to identify and develop high-potential employees through our NEXT program, which provides identified employees the opportunities to develop key leadership skills and work closely with both their peers around the world and members of our senior leadership team. We also seek to foster a culture of engagement with the aspiration of creating deeper connections among all our employees. We want all our employees to believe in our mission as a company, understand their role in executing our strategy and be passionate about DexKo and their careers. We conduct regular engagement surveys to provide us with valuable insights into our employee experiences and use the results to develop actions to implement focused activities to drive activities designed to address specific issues. We strive to keep our employees well informed and connected with regular updates from our CEO and other senior leaders, town halls and other activities. We believe DexKo has a responsibility to build and strengthen connections within our communities, and we sponsor a variety of community outreach and charitable activities in the communities in which we operate.

Our corporate headquarters is located in Novi, Michigan under a lease through 2027. We operate 50 manufacturing and assembly plants with over four million square feet of manufacturing space and 50 distribution locations. The leases for our manufacturing plants have initial terms that expire from 2021 through 2037, certain of which are renewable, at our option, for various terms, provided that we are not in default under the lease agreements. Our buildings have been well maintained, are in good operating condition, and are appropriate for current production requirements.

We are a party to ordinary and routine litigation incidental to our business. We do not expect the outcome of any pending litigation to have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity or financial position. 109 -----

Subsection Title: MANAGEMENT Executive Officers and Other Key Employees
Subsubsection Text: The following table sets forth certain information regarding the individuals who we expect will serve as the executive officers of the Company at the closing of the Acquisition.

Subsubsection Title: Fred Bentley has held the position of President and Chief Executive Officer of the Company since January
Subsubsection Text: 2016. He oversees the Dexter Axle and AL-KO global operations. Mr. Bentley has significant experience running global operations and growing businesses while working with world-class companies. Prior to joining the Company, Mr. Bentley was the CEO of Maxion Wheels, a $2.4 billion global automotive equipment supplier and the world’s largest wheel company. He oversaw the $1.2 billion European operation and lived in Germany for three years prior to becoming CEO of Maxion Wheels. He held the position of COO and President of International Operations of Hayes Lemmerz, leading the company’s sale process (to Iochpe-Maxion) and the divestitures of non-core businesses while significantly globalizing the core business. Prior experience also includes six years running an international business with significant operational experience at Honeywell/Allied Signal and seven years in operations, finance and strategy at Frito Lay. Mr. Bentley has also served on the board of directors of several companies since 2014. Mr. Bentley has a B.S. in Industrial Engineering from the University of Cincinnati and attended the Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program. In addition to his extensive experience in manufacturing companies, Mr. Bentley brings vast knowledge of the Company’s business, structure, history and culture to the board of directors and the CEO position.

Subsubsection Title: Matthew W. Hughes was named Chief Financial Officer of the Company in November 2020 and oversees the
Subsubsection Text: Dexter and AL-KO global financial organizations. Prior to joining the Company, Mr. Hughes was with IGT, a global leader in the gaming industry. During his 22 years with IGT, Mr. Hughes held several leadership positions including Treasurer, CFO of the Products and Services segment and Vice President of Business Evaluation. Prior to his departure, Mr. Hughes served as CFO for IGT’s International business. Mr. Hughes also served as Vice President and Treasurer of Nortek, a diversified manufacturer of air ventilation, security and ergonomic products. Mr. Hughes was part of the executive team responsible for the sale of Nortek in 2016. Mr. Hughes started his career with the global IT consulting firm Gartner. Mr. Hughes has extensive international experience that includes working and living abroad in Rome, Italy and London, England. Mr. Hughes has a B.S. degree in Accounting from Central Connecticut State University and an M.B.A. degree in Finance from Bryant University.

Subsubsection Title: William Meador II has served as the Chief Operating Officer of the Company since January 2016. Mr. Meador
Subsubsection Text: has 35 plus years of leadership responsibility focused on increasing profitability throughout global and domestic organizations. As COO of the Company, Mr. Meador is focused on driving cost improvements and positioning the Company to deliver profitable growth. Prior to joining the Company, Mr. Meador served as SVP North America for Haldex Brake Products Inc. Prior to Haldex, he led Motor Wheel CVS as CEO for seven years. Mr. Meador is a 1984 graduate of Marshall University with a Bachelor’s Degree in Business Management.

Subsubsection Title: Adam Dexter has served as Chief Executive Officer of Dexter since November 2012 and has served as
Subsubsection Text: President of Dexter since January 2008. Mr. Dexter joined Dexter in 1993. He is responsible for the overall vision, strategy and execution of Dexter’s growth and operational plans. Mr. Dexter has served in various management and executive roles with a steady and progressive increase in responsibilities which include Production Superintendent from March 1993 until April 1994, Plant Manager from April 1994 until December 1998, Director of Operations from December 1998 until May 2005, and Divisional President from May 2005 until December 2007. He led the 110 ----- 2008 and 2009 restructuring efforts that effectively mitigated the economic downturn and continued profitability as well as positioned Dexter for sustainable growth. He was instrumental in leading Dexter during its sale to Sterling. He has served on Dexter’s board of directors since November 2012. He is active in industry trade associations and has served on the board of directors for The Recreation Vehicle Industry Association from 2010 to 2019 and for the National Association of Trailer Manufacturers from 2011 to 2017. Mr. Dexter has a Bachelor’s Degree from DePauw University.

Subsubsection Title: Harald Hiller has served as Chief Executive Officer of AL-KO since September 2016 and has served as
Subsubsection Text: President of AL-KO since April 2015. Since 2006, he has been responsible for all facets of the AL-KO business. Mr. Hiller has a strong executive management and leadership track record and over 25 years of experience driving profitable growth within fast moving technology driven businesses. He has domestic and international experience in operations, P&L responsibility, new market identification and strategic positioning for a multimillion-dollar organization. Prior to his current role, Mr. Hiller was Senior Vice President Logistics and Production for AL-KO in Europe from 1999 through 2006 and Vice President of the main plants in Kötz, Germany from 1996 through 1999. Mr Hiller started his career as Head of Production and Electronic Manufacturing at Mannesmann Tally and Technical Director of Heidolph Instruments before joining AL-KO. Mr. Hiller holds a diploma in Engineering and Business Administration from the universities of applied sciences in Ulm and Rendsburg (Germany).

Subsubsection Title: Steven Esau has served as Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of the Company since April 2019.
Subsubsection Text: Prior to joining the Company, Mr. Esau was Vice President and General Counsel of Maxion Wheels from February 2012 until April 2019. Mr. Esau also served as Assistant General Counsel at Hayes Lemmerz International from October 2004 until the company was acquired by Maxion Wheels in February 2012. Prior to joining Hayes Lemmerz, Mr. Esau served as Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of Click2learn, Inc. a publicly traded enterprise software company. Prior to joining Click2learn, he was in private law practice, first with Stoel Rives LLP in Seattle and then with his own law firm. Mr. Esau received a B.A. in Economics and a J.D. from the University of Michigan and participated in the Executive Program at the Stephen M. Ross School of Business at the University of Michigan. 111 -----

We plan to enhance our position as an industry leader in the production and distribution of highly engineered components that are critical to the safety and performance of a broad range of applications. The key elements of our strategy to accomplish our vision are:

Subsubsection Title: Pandemics and unexpected events like COVID-19 have and could continue to have a negative effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows.
Subsubsection Text: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the global economy and, consequently, our business and operations have been, and may continue to be, adversely affected by the pandemic. In the late part of the first quarter and early part of the second quarter of 2020, we experienced significant demand volatility for our products, with significant demand reductions in the early part of the second quarter followed by very strong demand recovery in the second half. We could experience similar volatility in the future. The duration of the pandemic and the magnitude of its impact remain uncertain, and a prolonged or worsening disruption or a resulting economic recession could materially and adversely impact our business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows. The continuing surges of COVID-19 cases, along with new strains and variants being discovered and challenges associated with the roll out and availability of vaccines have resulted in the reimposition of certain restrictions in certain states and countries and may lead to other restrictions being implemented in response to efforts to reduce the spread of COVID-19. Accordingly, the COVID-19 outbreak has severely restricted the level of economic activity in many countries, continues to adversely impact global economic activity and has contributed to significant volatility in financial markets. Although most of our operations have been treated as “essential” operations under applicable government orders which restrict business activities, and accordingly have been permitted to continue to operate, it is possible that treatment as an “essential” business could change under future government orders or new restrictions may be added in response to the evolving conditions. Furthermore, some of our customers and suppliers may not be considered essential businesses, which could result in reduced demand or interruptions to our supply chain. We have experienced temporary shutdowns in certain facilities and we, our employees, suppliers or customers may be prevented from conducting business activities for an indefinite period of time, including shutdowns, shelter-in-place orders, employee quarantine requirements, import or export restrictions or other preventative measures that may be requested or mandated by governmental authorities. Further, site-specific health and safety concerns might otherwise require certain of our operations to be halted for some period of time, and we may experience significant absenteeism from COVID-19 infections and employee quarantines. Operations at our facilities have been modified for employee protection measures, including social distancing measures and enhanced cleaning regimens with greater frequency, which may continue to affect the efficiency of our operations for the foreseeable future. In addition, the facilities of our customers and suppliers may experience disruptions in manufacturing and supply arrangements due to the loss or disruption of essential manufacturing and supply elements, such as raw materials or other finished product components, transportation, workforce or other manufacturing and distribution capability. We may also experience failure of third parties on which we rely, including our suppliers, distributors, contractors and commercial banks, to meet their obligations to us, or significant disruptions in their ability to do so. To the extent the COVID-19 pandemic materially adversely affects our business and financial results, it may also have the effect of significantly heightening many of the other risks associated with our business, including those described in this offering memorandum. 34 -----

Subsubsection Title: Our business depends upon general economic conditions and, accordingly, volatility in the U.S. and global economic environments may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Our financial performance depends, in large part, on conditions in the end use segments that we serve and in both the U.S. and global economic environments. Historically, sales of our products have been subject to significant variations caused by volatility in such end use segments. Any future economic recession may impact leveraged companies like us more than competing companies with less leverage and may adversely affect our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. If we are unable to sufficiently adjust to market conditions, we could fail to deliver on planned results, fall short of analyst and investor expectations, incur higher fixed costs, and/or fail to benefit from higher than expected customer demand resulting in loss of market share, among other potential adverse effects on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: The financial stability of our customers, some of whom serve cyclical industries, could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Financial instability at any of our customers could impair our ability to collect receivables from those customers or limit their ability to purchase our products. In addition to being impacted by this type of general instability, some of the end-use segments in which our products are used are subject to periods of volatility, such as agricultural, construction, livestock, industrial, marine, military, recreation, trailer and utility. These end-use segments are subject to additional risk based on industrial conditions in those specific end-use segments. The COVID-19 pandemic and changes to the economic environment may also cause our customers to experience cash flow problems and, thus, result in them having difficulty obtaining financing for their businesses. As a result, our customers’ need for and ability to purchase our products or services may decrease. Any inability of customers to pay us for our products and services, or to continue to purchase our products and services, may materially and adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: The financial stability of our suppliers and the ability of our suppliers to produce quality materials could adversely affect our ability to obtain timely and cost-effective raw materials and other inputs used in the manufacturing process.
Subsubsection Text: Financial instability at several of our suppliers, which may be caused by, among other things, the COVID-19 pandemic, could disrupt our ability to obtain certain inputs used in the manufacture of our products. Some of our suppliers may not be successful in generating sufficient sales or securing financing for the operation of their businesses, and therefore may no longer be able to supply goods and services to us. In that event, we would need to find additional sources for goods and services, and we might not be able to find such additional sources on favorable terms, if at all. Our suppliers may demand different payment terms, increase their prices, reduce their output or change their terms of sale, any of which could impact our cash flows and margins. Any such disruption in our supply chain could adversely affect our ability to manufacture and deliver our products on a timely basis and thereby affect our results of operations and financial condition. In addition, changes in the availability and price of raw materials, components and whole goods, which have fluctuated significantly in the past and are more likely to fluctuate during times of economic volatility and regulatory instability, can significantly increase the costs of production which could have a material negative effect on the profitability of the business, particularly if, due to pricing considerations or other factors, we are unable to recover the increased costs from our customers.

Subsubsection Title: Inability to meet demand could result in the loss of customers.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to fulfill customer orders is dependent on a well-functioning supply chain and our manufacturing and distribution operations. Although we forecast demand, additional plant capacity takes months to bring online, and thus increases in demand could result in longer lead times. Furthermore, shortages in raw materials, components or transportation capacity could also impact our production schedules and result in longer lead times or an inability to meet customer demand. We cannot guarantee that we will be able to increase manufacturing capacity or source the necessary raw materials and components to meet higher product demand, which could prevent us from meeting increased customer demand. However, if demand varies significantly from our projections and we overbuild our capacity, we may have underutilized assets. For example, the current COVID-19 pandemic has caused 35 ----- manufacturing and distribution disruptions and temporary shutdowns of business at some of our customers and suppliers. These shutdowns, combined with decreased customer demand, has at times resulted in decreased manufacturing levels. Efficient operations also require streamlining processes to maintain or reduce lead times, which we may not be capable of achieving. Unacceptable levels of service for key customers may result if we are not able to fulfill orders on a timely basis or if product quality or warranty or safety issues result from compromised production. We may not be able to adjust our production schedules to reflect changes in customer demand on a timely basis. Due to the complexity of our manufacturing operations, we may be unable to timely respond to fluctuations in demand.

Subsubsection Title: International, national and regional trade laws, regulations and policies (particularly those related to or restricting global trade) could significantly impair our profitability and growth prospects.
Subsubsection Text: International, national and regional laws, regulations and policies directly or indirectly related to or restricting the import and export of our products, services and technology, including protectionist policies in particular jurisdictions or for the benefit of favored industries or sectors, could harm our multinational business. Our profitability and growth prospects are affected by the global marketplace. Restricted access to global markets could impair our ability to export goods and services from our various manufacturing locations around the world, and could limit the ability to access raw materials and high-quality parts and components at competitive prices on a timely basis. Trade restrictions, including potential limitations on existing trade agreements and trade terms, could limit our ability to capitalize on current and future growth opportunities in international markets and impair our ability to expand the business by offering new technologies, products and services. These restrictions may affect our competitive position. Additionally, our competitive position and results could be adversely affected by changes in-or uncertainty surrounding-U.S. trade policy. Furthermore, the violation of any trade restrictions or of sanctions and export controls imposed by the U.S. and other governments restricting or prohibiting transactions with certain persons, including financial institutions, to certain countries, or involving certain products could expose us to potential criminal and civil sanctions. Embargoes and sanctions laws are changing rapidly for certain geographies, including with respect to Russia, Cuba, Iran and Sudan. Although we have a compliance program in place designed to reduce the likelihood of potential violations of import and export laws and sanctions, violations of these laws or sanctions could have an adverse effect on our reputation, business and results of operations and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: The uncertainty surrounding the effect of Brexit and related negative developments in the European Union could adversely affect our business and financial results. The withdrawal of the U.K. from the European Union could adversely affect us.
Subsubsection Text: In a Referendum of the U.K. held on June 23, 2016, the U.K. voted to leave the European Union (E.U.) (referred to as Brexit) and on January 31, 2020, the U.K. formally withdrew from the E.U. The transition period provided for in the withdrawal agreement entered by the U.K. and the E.U. ended on December 31, 2020. On December 24, 2020, the U.K. and the E.U. agreed on a trade and cooperation agreement. The trade and cooperation agreement covers the general objectives and framework of the relationship between the U.K. and the E.U., including as it relates to trade, transport, visas, judicial, law enforcement and security matters, and provides for continued participation in community programs and mechanisms for dispute resolution. The terms of Brexit and the U.K.’s relationship with the E.U. going forward will continue to be uncertain for global companies like ours. Our operations in the U.K. serve primarily customers located within the U.K. However, they source materials from our locations, and from third parties, in the E.U. and elsewhere. The ongoing uncertainly could cause disruptions to and create uncertainty surrounding our business, including affecting our relationships with our existing and future customers, suppliers and employees, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial results and operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our operations and success may be impacted by natural disasters, pandemics, terrorism, acts of war, international conflict and political and governmental actions, which could harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: Natural disasters, pandemics, acts or threats of war or terrorism, international conflicts and the actions taken by the U.S. and other governments in response to such events could cause damage or disrupt our business operations, our suppliers or our customers, and could create political or economic instability, any of which could have an 36 ----- adverse effect on our business. Although it is not possible to predict such events or their consequences, these events could decrease demand for our products, could make it difficult or impossible for us to deliver products or could disrupt our supply chain. We may also be impacted by actions by foreign governments where our facilities are located, including currency devaluation, tariffs and nationalization, which could disrupt manufacturing and commercial operations.

Subsubsection Title: We face competition in all areas of our business and may not be able to compete successfully, causing us to lose market share and sales.
Subsubsection Text: We operate in a variety of competitive markets. We compete with other manufacturers and distributors that produce and sell similar products. We compete based on product design, product quality, timeliness of delivery, product performance, innovation, geographic coverage, distribution, customer service and price. Some of our competitors have established brands and may have greater financial, marketing, manufacturing and distribution resources than we do. As a result, they may be able to adapt more quickly to new or emerging technologies and changes in customer preferences, or devote greater resources to the development, promotion and sale of their products than we can. Furthermore, the entry of new companies may encourage existing competitors to consolidate their operations, expand their products lines, or intensify efforts within existing product lines. In addition, subsidies offered by governmental entities continue to drive the development and adoption of various alternative technologies. This competition, coupled with aggressive pricing or other strategies pursued by competitors, unanticipated product or manufacturing delays or our failure to price our products competitively could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: Our products are typically highly engineered or customer-driven and we are subject to risks associated with changing technology and manufacturing techniques that could place us at a competitive disadvantage.
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our customers rigorously evaluate their suppliers on the basis of product quality, price competitiveness, technical expertise and development capability, new product innovation, reliability and timeliness of delivery, product design capability, manufacturing expertise, operational flexibility, customer service and overall management. Our success depends on our ability to continue to meet our customers’ changing expectations with respect to these criteria. We may be unable to address technological advances, implement new and more costeffective manufacturing techniques, or introduce new or improved products, whether in existing or new end-use segments, so as to maintain our businesses’ competitive positions or to grow our businesses as desired. If we do not adequately anticipate the changing needs of our customers by developing and introducing new and effective products and technologies on a timely basis, our competitive position and prospects could be harmed. We anticipate that we will remain committed to product R&D, advanced manufacturing techniques and outstanding customer service to remain competitive. However, the R&D process is time consuming and costly and the results are often uncertain. Our ability to introduce new and improved products may be constrained by the patents and other intellectual property rights of competitors and others. We believe that we have certain technological advantages over our competitors, but there is no guarantee that we will be successful in maintaining these advantages, and some of our products could become commoditized. Furthermore, any new products that we develop may not receive market acceptance or otherwise generate any meaningful net sales or profits for us relative to our expectations. Additionally, product quality and reliability are determined in part by factors that are not entirely within our control. We depend on our suppliers for parts and components that meet our standards. If our suppliers fail to meet those standards, we may not be able to deliver the quality products that our customers expect within the expected delivery times. If any of these events occur, it could cause decreases in sales, a failure to realize premium pricing and an adverse effect on our business and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: Our business depends on our strong brands. If we are not able to maintain and enhance our brands, we may be unable to sell our products.
Subsubsection Text: Our flagship brands, Dexter in North America and AL-KO in Europe, have strong recognition in their particular regions. In addition, many of our other brands such as CM Trailers, Kodiak, Redline, Redneck, Rockwell American, 37 ----- Silent Drive, Aguti, Bankside Patterson, CBE, E&P Hydraulics, Nordelettronica, Safim, Sawiko and G&S Chassis are well known in their respective end-use segments. Our success depends on our ability to maintain and enhance our brand image and reputation. In particular, we believe that maintaining and enhancing our strong brands is critical to maintaining and expanding our customer base. Maintaining, promoting and enhancing our brands may require us to make substantial investments in areas such as product innovation, product quality, intellectual property protection, marketing and employee training, and these investments may not have the desired impact on our brands’ image and reputation. Our business could be adversely impacted if we fail to achieve any of these objectives or if the reputation or image of any of our brands is tarnished or receives negative publicity. In addition, adverse publicity about regulatory or legal action against us could damage our reputation and image and reduce long-term demand for our products, even if the regulatory or legal action is unfounded or not material to our operations. If we are unable to maintain or enhance the image of our brands, it could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We do not own the trademark to the “AL-KO” name, but we may use it pursuant to a trademark license entered into in connection with our 2015 acquisition of AL-KO. Use of the “AL-KO” name by other parties or the termination of our trademark license agreement may harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with our acquisition of AL-KO at the end of 2015, we entered into a trademark license agreement (the “Trademark License Agreement”) with AL-KO Kober SE (the “Licensor”) pursuant to which the Licensor has granted us an exclusive, perpetual, paid-up, royalty-free, non-divisible and nontransferable worldwide license to continue to use the “AL-KO” name and trademarks in connection with the acquired trailer components, motorized chassis and automotive businesses. The “AL-KO” name is our flagship brand in Europe. Although the Trademark License Agreement is perpetual, it may be terminated by either party upon written notice if the other party commits a breach of its obligations, subject to a thirty-day cure period. In the event that the Trademark License Agreement is terminated and we are precluded from using the AL-KO name and trademarks, the transition to a different brand (whether new or existing in our portfolio) would be time consuming and expensive, could disrupt our recognition in the marketplace and could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, pursuant to the terms of our 2015 acquisition of AL-KO, Licensor and its affiliates retain certain rights to use the “AL-KO” name and trademarks for their own business purposes outside the scope of the license granted to us under the Trademark License Agreement. Any improper use of the “AL-KO” name by, or damage to goodwill that may occur as a result of the activities of, Licensor, its affiliates or any other third parties could damage any goodwill we may have generated and otherwise materially adversely affect our business.

Subsubsection Title: Our failure to maintain good relationships with our distributors or the actions or inactions of our distributors could have an adverse effect on our results of operations and our ability to generate cash flow.
Subsubsection Text: If we fail to maintain good relationships with our distributors, we could lose a substantial amount of our distributor base. A loss of a substantial portion of our distributor base could cause our sales to decline significantly, which would have an adverse effect on our results of operations and ability to generate cash flow. In addition, our distributors may not provide timely or adequate service to our end-users. If this occurs, our brand identity and reputation may be damaged, which would have an adverse effect on our results of operations and ability to generate cash flow.

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to accurately forecast demand or meet significant increases in demand for our products.
Subsubsection Text: We often operate with short lead times and we order raw materials and supplies and plan production based on discussions with our customers and internal forecasts of demand. If we are unable to accurately forecast demand for our products, in terms of both volume and specific products, or react appropriately to increases in demand, or if we experience shortages of raw materials or components or other supply chain disruptions, we may experience delayed product shipments and customer dissatisfaction. If demand increases significantly from current levels, both we and our suppliers may have difficulty meeting such demand, particularly if such demand increases occur rapidly. Additionally, we may carry excess inventory if demand for our products decreases below projected levels. Failure to accurately forecast demand or meet significant increases in demand could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and operating results. 38 -----

Subsubsection Title: We may not achieve our projected business initiatives in the time periods that we anticipate, or at all, which could have an adverse effect on our business, operating results, and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We set goals and objectives for the timing of certain accomplishments, initiatives and milestones regarding our business or operating results. Whether we achieve our goals and objectives can vary due to a number of factors, including the risk factors described herein. As a result, there can be no assurance that we will succeed in achieving our goals and objectives of our initiatives in the time periods that we anticipate, or ever. The failure to achieve such goals and objectives in the time periods that we anticipate, or at all, could have an adverse effect on our business, operating results and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on the continued operation of our manufacturing facilities and we may need to make investments in new or existing facilities.
Subsubsection Text: We may need to make investments in new or existing manufacturing facilities to adapt our production capacity to changing market conditions and to align with our growth strategies. The costs of such investments may be significant and we may not realize the expected benefits on our anticipated timeframe or at all, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We may be subject to further unionization at our facilities or we or our customers may be subject to work stoppages, which could seriously impact the profitability of our business.
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2021, we employed approximately 7,000 people worldwide. Approximately 11% of our employees in North America were employed under collective bargaining agreements with industrial trade unions and approximately 67% of our employees in non-North American countries (the “Rest of World”) were employed under international unions or workers’ councils. Our collective bargaining agreements and agreements with workers’ councils are renegotiated periodically, and we cannot predict the outcome of these negotiations. If we are unable to reach new agreements or renew existing agreements on a timely basis, we may experience issues which may disrupt our operations. We are not aware of any present active union organizing drives at any of our other facilities, but we cannot predict the impact of any further unionization of our workplace. Increased unionization of our workforce, new labor legislation or changes in regulations could disrupt our operations, reduce our profitability or interfere with the ability of our management to focus on executing business strategies. Furthermore, many of our direct or indirect customers have unionized workforces. Strikes, work stoppages or slowdowns experienced by these customers or their suppliers could result in slowdowns or closures of assembly plants where our products are included. In addition, organizations responsible for shipping our customers’ products may be impacted by occasional strikes or other activity. Any interruption in the delivery of our customers’ products could reduce demand for our products and could have a material adverse effect on us.

Subsubsection Title: We may not realize all of the anticipated benefits of our acquisitions or divestitures, including the Acquisition, or these benefits may take longer to realize than expected, and may experience difficulty in integrating acquired businesses.
Subsubsection Text: Our long-term growth strategy includes building value for our company through a variety of methods. These methods may include the acquisition of, investment in, or joint ventures involving, complementary businesses and divestitures. We may not be able to identify a sufficient number of suitable parties for these transactions or complete transactions with the parties we do identify. If we are unable to identify suitable parties or to complete strategic transactions on commercially acceptable terms we may not be able to capitalize on market opportunities with existing and new customers, which could inhibit our ability to gain market share. Transactions that we have entered into, including the Acquisition, or may enter into in the future, may involve significant challenges and risks, including that the transactions do not advance our business strategy, or fail to produce satisfactory returns on our investment. Our ability to realize the anticipated benefits of our acquisitions will depend, to a large extent, on our ability to integrate the acquired businesses with our business. The integration of independent businesses is a complex, costly and time-consuming process. As a result, we may be required to devote significant management attention and resources to integrating the business practices and operations of any acquired 39 ----- businesses with ours. Our failure to meet the challenges involved in integrating an acquired business into our existing operations or otherwise to realize the anticipated benefits of the transaction could cause an interruption of, or a loss of momentum in, our activities and could adversely affect our results of operations. In addition, the overall integration of our acquired businesses may result in material unanticipated problems, expenses, liabilities, competitive responses, loss of customer relationships and diversion of management’s attention. The difficulties of combining the operations of acquired businesses with ours include, among others: - managing a larger company; - disruption of our existing operations and plans; - integrating business cultures, which may prove to be incompatible; - consolidating corporate and administrative infrastructures and eliminating duplicative operations; - unanticipated issues in integrating information technology, communications and other systems; - managing tax costs or inefficiencies associated with integrating the operations of the combined company; - unforeseen expenses or delays associated with the acquisition; - difficulty comparing financial reports due to differing financial and/or internal reporting systems; - making any necessary modifications to internal financial control standards; - inability to successfully integrate or develop a distribution channel for acquired product lines; - potential loss of key employees, customers, distributors, or dealers of the acquired businesses or adverse effects on existing business relationships with suppliers, customers, distributors, and dealers; - adverse impact on overall profitability if our expanded operations do not achieve the financial results projected in our valuation models; - reallocation of amounts of capital from other operating initiatives and/or an increase in our leverage and debt service requirements to pay acquisition purchase prices or other business venture investment costs, which could in turn restrict our ability to access additional capital when needed or pursue other important elements of our business strategy; - failure by acquired businesses or other business ventures to comply with applicable international, federal, and state product safety or other regulatory standards; - inaccurate assessment of additional post-acquisition or business venture investments, undisclosed, contingent or other liabilities or problems, unanticipated costs associated with an acquisition or other business venture, and an inability to recover or manage such liabilities and costs; and - write-off of significant amounts of goodwill or other assets as a result of deterioration in the performance of an acquired business or product line, adverse market conditions, changes in the competitive landscape, changes in laws or regulations that restrict activities of an acquired business or product line, or as a result of a variety of other circumstances. Many of these factors will be outside of our control and any one of them could result in increased costs, decreases in the amount of expected revenues and diversion of management’s time and energy, which could materially impact our business, financial condition and results of operations. While our evaluation of any potential transaction includes business, legal, environmental and financial due diligence with the goal of identifying and evaluating the material risks involved, our due diligence reviews may not identify all of the issues necessary to accurately estimate the cost and potential risks of a particular transaction, including potential exposure to regulatory 40 ----- sanctions resulting from an acquisition target’s previous activities or costs associated with any quality issues with an acquisition target’s products or services. In addition, even if the operations of our acquired businesses are integrated successfully with our operations, we may not realize the full benefits of the transaction, including the synergies, cost savings or sales or growth opportunities that we expect. These benefits may not be achieved within the anticipated time frame, or at all, or additional unanticipated costs may be incurred in the integration of our businesses. All of these factors could adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. As a result, we cannot assure you that the combination of our acquisitions with our business will result in the realization of the full benefits anticipated from such transaction, including the Acquisition.

Subsubsection Title: Our ability to execute our strategy is dependent upon our ability to attract, train and retain qualified personnel.
Subsubsection Text: The success of our business is largely dependent on our senior management team, led by our Chief Executive Officer, our Chief Financial Officer and other key high level managers. The loss of the services of any of these key employees could disrupt our operations and have an adverse effect on our business. Our capacity to meet strategic objectives, and otherwise grow our business, is also dependent on our ability to identify, attract, recruit, motivate, train, retain and engage highly qualified and diverse personnel in key functions with the requisite education, background and industry experience. Failure to attract, train and retain qualified personnel, including production personnel, whether as a result of an insufficient number of qualified applicants, difficulty in recruiting new personnel, or the allocation of inadequate resources to training, integration and retention of qualified personnel, could impair our ability to execute our business strategy and could adversely affect our business and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: As we seek to expand our business globally, growth opportunities may be impacted by greater political, economic and social uncertainty and the continuing and accelerating globalization of businesses could significantly change the dynamics of our competition, customer base and product offerings.
Subsubsection Text: Our efforts to grow our business may include entering or expanding in additional geographic markets and developing market share and operating profitably in such markets. In some cases, these countries have greater political and economic volatility, greater vulnerability to infrastructure and labor disruptions and differing local customer product preferences and requirements than our other markets. Operating and seeking to expand business in a number of different regions and countries exposes us to multiple and potentially conflicting cultural practices, business practices and legal and regulatory requirements that are subject to change, including those related to tariffs and trade barriers, investments, property ownership rights, taxation, sanctions requirements, repatriation of earnings and advanced technologies. Expanding business operations globally also increases exposure to currency fluctuations which can materially affect our financial results. As these emerging geographic markets become more important to us, our competitors may also expand their production capacities and sales in these same markets. While we maintain a positive corporate image and our brands are widely recognized and valued in our traditional markets, our brands are less well known in some emerging markets which could impede our efforts to successfully compete in these markets. Our reputation and/or business results could be negatively affected should our efforts to adapt to these circumstances prove unsuccessful.

Subsubsection Title: Security breaches and other disruptions to our information technology infrastructure could interfere with our operations and could compromise our and our customers’ and suppliers’ information, exposing us to liability that would cause our business and reputation to suffer.
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of business, we rely upon information technology networks and systems, some of which are managed by third parties, to process, transmit and store electronic information, and to manage or support a variety of business processes and activities, including supply chain, manufacturing, distribution, invoicing and collection of payments from customers. We use information technology systems to record, process and summarize financial information and results of operations for internal reporting purposes and to comply with regulatory financial reporting, legal and tax requirements. Additionally, we collect and store sensitive data, including intellectual property, proprietary business information and the proprietary business information of our customers and suppliers, as well as personal identifiable information of our customers and employees, in data centers and on information technology networks. The secure operation of these information technology networks and the processing and maintenance of this information is critical to our business operations and strategy. Despite security measures and business continuity plans, our information technology networks and infrastructure and those of our customers and suppliers have in the past been, and may in the future be, vulnerable to damage, disruptions or 41 ----- shutdowns due to attacks by cyber-criminals or breaches due to employee error or malfeasance or other disruptions during the process of upgrading or replacing computer software or hardware, power outages, computer viruses, malware, ransomware, denial-of-service attacks, phishing, social engineering, telecommunication or utility failures, terrorist acts or natural disasters or other catastrophic events. Government agencies and security experts have warned about growing risks of hackers, cyber-criminals, malicious insiders and other actors targeting confidential information and all types of information technology (“IT”) systems, and such risks are constantly evolving as malicious attacks become increasingly sophisticated. Although we maintain insurance coverage for various cybersecurity and business continuity risks, there can be no guarantee that all costs or losses incurred will be fully insured, or that such insurance will continue to be available on reasonable terms or at all. Changes in our insurance policies, including premium increases or the imposition of large deductible or coinsurance requirements, could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Malicious actors may engage in fraudulent activities, theft of confidential or proprietary information and sabotage. The occurrence of any of these events could compromise our networks, and the information stored there could be accessed, publicly disclosed, lost or stolen. Any such access, disclosure or other loss of information could result in legal claims or proceedings, liability or regulatory penalties under laws protecting the privacy of personal information, disruption of operations, and damage to our reputation, which could adversely affect our business. Our data is subject to a variety of U.S. and international laws and regulations that pertain to the collection and handling of personal information. The laws require us to notify governmental authorities and affected individuals of data breaches involving certain personal information. As the threats evolve and become more potent, we may incur additional costs to secure our data and infrastructure of our networks.

Subsubsection Title: We have a history of operating losses and we may not achieve or maintain profitability in the future.
Subsubsection Text: We have not been profitable and may not achieve or maintain profitability in the future. As of June 30, 2021, we had an accumulated deficit of $43.2 million. These losses have resulted principally from depreciation and amortization, interest and administrative expenses. We also expect our costs to increase in future periods in order to drive organic growth, pursue and integrate acquisitions and expand into new markets, and we may not be able to increase our net sales enough to offset our higher operating expenses. We may incur significant losses in the future for a number of other reasons, including the other risks described in this offering memorandum, and unforeseen expenses, difficulties, complications and delays, and other unknown events. While we believe our growth strategy will help us achieve profitability, there can be no guarantee.

Subsubsection Title: Our consolidated financial results are reported in U.S. dollars, while certain assets and other reported items are denominated in the currencies of other countries, creating currency exchange and translation risk.
Subsubsection Text: We operate in many areas of the world, involving transactions denominated in a variety of currencies. We are subject to currency exchange risk to the extent that our costs are denominated in currencies other than those in which we earn revenues. Additionally, the reporting currency for our consolidated financial statements is the U.S. dollar. Certain of our assets, liabilities, expenses and revenues are denominated in other countries’ currencies. Those assets, liabilities, expenses and revenues are translated into U.S. dollars at the applicable exchange rates to prepare our consolidated financial statements. Therefore, increases or decreases in exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and those other currencies affect the value of those items as reflected in our consolidated financial statements, even if their value remains unchanged in their original currency. Substantial fluctuations in the value of the U.S. dollar could have a significant impact on our financial condition and results of operations. We anticipate that there will be instances in which costs and revenues will not be exactly matched with respect to currency denomination. As a result, to the extent we continue to expand geographically, we expect that increasing portions of our revenues, costs, assets and liabilities will be subject to fluctuations in foreign currency valuations. We may experience economic loss and a negative impact on earnings or net assets solely as a result of foreign 42 ----- currency exchange rate fluctuations. Further, the markets in which we operate could restrict the removal or conversion of the local or foreign currency, resulting in our inability to hedge against these risks. We also face risks arising from the imposition of exchange controls and currency devaluations. Exchange controls may limit our ability to convert foreign currencies into U.S. dollars or to remit dividends and other payments by our foreign subsidiaries or businesses located in or conducted within a country imposing controls. Currency devaluations result in a diminished value of funds denominated in the currency of the country instituting the devaluation. Actions of this nature, if they occur or continue for significant periods of time, could have an adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition in any given period.

Subsubsection Title: We have significant intangible assets, and future impairment could have a material negative impact on our financial results.
Subsubsection Text: Our total assets include goodwill and other intangible assets from acquisitions. As of June 30, 2021, our intangible assets were $2,032.5 million and represented 67% of our total assets. If we experience declines in sales and operating profit or do not meet our current and forecasted operating budget, we may be subject to future intangible asset impairments. Because of the significance of our intangible assets, any future impairment of these assets could have a material adverse effect on our financial results. Pursuant to GAAP, we are required to assess our goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets to determine if they are impaired on an annual basis, or more often if events or changes in circumstances indicate that impairment may have occurred. Intangible assets with finite lives are amortized over their useful life and are reviewed for impairment upon triggering events such as events or changes in circumstances indicating that an impairment may have occurred. If the testing performed indicates that impairment has occurred, we are required to record a non-cash impairment charge for the difference between the carrying value of the goodwill and the implied fair value of the goodwill or the carrying value of the intangible assets and the fair value of the intangible assets in the period the determination is made. Disruptions to our business, end market conditions, protracted economic weakness and unexpected significant declines in operating results may result in charges for goodwill and other asset impairments. The carrying value of long-lived assets is evaluated whenever events or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of a long-lived asset may not be recoverable. Events or circumstances that would result in an impairment review primarily include a significant change in the use of an asset, a significant change in the projected future cash flows generated by an asset or the planned sale or disposal of an asset. The asset would be considered impaired when there is no future use planned for the asset or the future net undiscounted cash flows generated by the asset or asset group are less than its carrying value. An impairment loss would be recognized based on the amount by which the carrying value exceeds fair value and could have a material adverse effect on the results of our operations.

Subsubsection Title: We have significant lease obligations and our failure to meet those obligations could adversely affect our financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We lease many of our manufacturing facilities and certain capital equipment. Our lease expense for the six months ended June 30, 2021 under these leases was $14.2 million. A failure to pay our lease obligations would constitute a default allowing the applicable landlord to pursue any remedy available to it under applicable law, which would include taking possession of our property and, in the case of real property, evicting us.

Subsubsection Title: Sustained increases in funding obligations under our pension plans may impair our liquidity or financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We maintain certain defined benefit pension plans for certain employees, which impose funding obligations. Our pension expense and required contributions to our pension plans are directly affected by the value of plan assets, the projected rate of return on plan assets, the actual rate of return on plan assets and the actuarial assumptions we use to measure the defined benefit pension plan obligations. Significant adverse changes in credit or market conditions could result in assets performing below expectations. Under such circumstances, we may be required to increase our future pension expense and funding obligations, and thereby negatively impact our business, results of operations and cash flow. 43 -----

Subsubsection Title: Changes in tax rates, tax legislation, or exposure to additional tax liabilities could have a negative effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and numerous foreign jurisdictions. Our domestic and international tax liabilities are dependent upon the location of earnings among these different jurisdictions. Tax rates in various jurisdictions may be subject to significant change. Our effective tax rates could be affected by changes in the mix of earnings in countries with differing statutory tax rates, changes in the valuation of deferred tax assets and liabilities, or changes in tax laws or their interpretation. If our effective tax rates were to increase, or if the ultimate determination of our taxes owed is for an amount in excess of amounts previously accrued, our operating results, cash flows and financial condition could be adversely affected. Additionally, tax rates, tax laws or their implementation, and applicable tax authority practices in any particular jurisdiction could change on a retroactive basis, and any such change could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. We are also subject to the prevailing tax laws and the continuous examination of our income tax returns by tax authorities. The results of audits and examinations of previously filed tax returns and continuing assessments of our tax exposures may have an adverse effect on our provision for income taxes and cash tax liability.

Subsubsection Title: We may incur material losses and costs as a result of product liability, recall and warranty claims that may be brought against us.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to a variety of litigation incidental to our business, including claims for damages arising out of use of our products, claims relating to intellectual property matters and claims involving employment matters and commercial disputes. While we believe that we appropriately instruct our customers on the proper usage of our products, we cannot ensure that they will implement our instructions accurately or completely. If our products are defective or used incorrectly by our customers, injury may result. Furthermore, other product defects may occur through our own product development, design, and manufacturing processes. Any losses that we may suffer from any liability claims, and the effect that any product liability litigation may have upon the reputation and marketability of our products, may divert management’s attention from other matters and may have a negative impact on our business and operating results. Additionally, we could experience a material design or manufacturing failure in our products or other safety issues, or heightened regulatory scrutiny that could warrant a recall of some of our products. A recall of some of our products could also result in increased product liability claims. Any of these issues could also result in loss of market share, reduced sales and higher warranty expense. We currently carry insurance and maintain reserves, which we believe to be adequate for potential product liability claims. However, our insurance coverage may be inadequate if such claims do arise and any liability not covered by insurance could have a material adverse effect on our business. Although we have been able to obtain insurance in amounts we believe to be appropriate to cover such liability to date, our insurance premiums may increase in the future as a consequence of conditions in the insurance business generally or our situation in particular. Any such increase could result in lower net income or cause the need to reduce our insurance coverage. In addition, a future claim may be brought against us that could have a material adverse effect on us. Any product liability claim may also include the imposition of punitive damages, the award of which, pursuant to certain state laws, may not be covered by insurance. Our product liability insurance policies have limits that, if exceeded, may result in material costs that could have an adverse effect on our future profitability. In addition, warranty claims are generally not covered by our product liability insurance. Further, any product liability or warranty issues may adversely affect our reputation as a manufacturer of high-quality, safe products, divert management’s attention, and could have a material adverse effect on our business.

Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to adequately protect our intellectual property.
Subsubsection Text: We consider our intellectual property rights to be important assets, and seek to protect them through a combination of patent, trademark, copyright and trade secret laws, as well as licensing and confidentiality 44 ----- agreements. These protections may not be adequate to prevent third parties from using our intellectual property without our authorization, breaching any confidentiality agreements with us, copying or reverse engineering our products or developing and marketing products that are substantially equivalent to or superior to our own. In addition, we attempt to protect our intellectual property, technology and confidential information by requiring our employees and consultants to enter into confidentiality and assignment of inventions agreements. These agreements may be breached and may not effectively grant all necessary rights to any inventions that may have been developed by the employees and consultants. In addition, these agreements may not have been signed by the employees of companies we have acquired or may acquire in the future. The unauthorized use of our intellectual property by others could reduce our competitive advantage and harm our business. We cannot guarantee that any patents, issued or pending, will provide us with any competitive advantage or will not be challenged by third parties. Moreover, the expiration of our patents may lead to increased competition with respect to certain products. The ability to obtain, maintain, protect and enforce intellectual property rights varies across jurisdictions and the laws of some foreign countries do not protect intellectual property rights to the same extent as federal and state laws in the United States. We rely on trade secret protection and confidentiality agreements to protect proprietary knowhow that is not patentable or that we elect not to patent and any other elements of our products that involve proprietary know-how, information or technology that is not covered by patents. However, trade secrets can be difficult to protect and some courts inside and outside the United States are less willing or unwilling to protect trade secrets. An inability to preserve our intellectual property rights may adversely affect our financial performance. Patents have a limited term. In the United States, the expiration of a patent is generally 20 years after its first effective non-provisional filing date. The patenting process is expensive and time-consuming, and we may not be able to file and prosecute or license all necessary or desirable patent applications at a reasonable cost or in a timely manner. Even if the patents do successfully issue, third parties may challenge the validity, enforceability or scope thereof in courts or patent offices, which may result in such patents being narrowed, invalidated or held unenforceable. Furthermore, even if they are unchallenged, our patents and patent applications may not adequately protect our intellectual property or prevent others from designing around our claims. Competitors and others may also initiate litigation to challenge the validity of our intellectual property or allege that we infringe on their intellectual property. Protecting or defending against such claims could significantly increase our costs, divert management’s time and attention away from other business matters and otherwise adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition. In addition, we cannot be certain that we do not or will not infringe third parties’ intellectual property rights. Any such claim, even if it is without merit, may be expensive and time-consuming to defend, subject us to damages, cause us to cease making, using or selling certain products that incorporate the disputed intellectual property, require us to redesign our products, divert management time and attention and/or require us to enter into costly royalty or licensing arrangements. We may be required to pay substantial damages if it is determined our products infringe on their intellectual property. We may also be required to develop an alternative, non-infringing product that could be costly and time-consuming, or acquire a license on terms that are not favorable to us. Not only are intellectual property-related proceedings burdensome and costly, but they could take years to resolve and we might not ultimately prevail. Our current and future trademark applications in the United States and in foreign jurisdictions may not be allowed or may subsequently be opposed. Once filed and registered, our trademarks or trade names may be challenged, infringed, circumvented or declared generic or determined to be infringing on other marks. As a means to enforce our trademark rights and prevent infringement, we may be required to file trademark claims against third parties or initiate trademark opposition proceedings. This can be expensive and time-consuming, particularly for a company of our size. We may not be able to protect our rights to these trademarks and trade names, which we need to build name recognition among potential partners or customers in our markets of interest. At times, competitors may adopt trade names or trademarks similar to ours, thereby impeding our ability to build brand identity and possibly leading to market confusion. In addition, there could be potential trade name or trademark infringement claims brought by owners of other registered trademarks or trademarks that incorporate variations of our registered or unregistered trademarks or trade names. While we believe that our patents, trademarks and other intellectual property have significant value, it is uncertain that this intellectual property or any intellectual property acquired or developed by us in the future, will 45 ----- provide a meaningful competitive advantage. Our patents or pending applications may be challenged, invalidated or circumvented by competitors or rights granted thereunder may not provide meaningful proprietary protection. Our efforts to enforce or protect our proprietary rights related to patents, trademarks, trade secrets, domain names, copyrights or other intellectual property may be ineffective and could result in substantial costs and diversion of resources. Policing unauthorized use of our intellectual property is difficult and expensive, and we may not be able to, or have the resources to, prevent misappropriation of our proprietary rights, particularly in countries where the laws may not protect such rights as fully as in the U.S.

Subsubsection Title: We may face liability associated with the use of products for which patent ownership or other intellectual property rights are claimed.
Subsubsection Text: We may be subject to claims or inquiries regarding alleged unauthorized use of a third party’s intellectual property. An adverse outcome in any intellectual property litigation could subject us to significant liabilities to third parties, require us to license technology or other intellectual property rights from others, require us to comply with injunctions to cease marketing or using certain products or brands, or require us to redesign, re-engineer, or re-brand certain products or packaging, any of which could affect our business, financial condition and operating results. If we are required to seek licenses under patents or other intellectual property rights of others, we may not be able to acquire these licenses on acceptable terms, if at all. In addition, the cost of responding to an intellectual property infringement claim, in terms of legal fees and expenses and the diversion of management resources, whether or not the claim is valid, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: Our operations are subject to various environmental, health and safety laws and regulations and our business may be materially and adversely affected by compliance obligations and liabilities under such laws and regulations.
Subsubsection Text: Our operations are subject to a variety of federal, state and local environmental, health and safety laws and regulations including those governing, among other things, climate change, emissions to air, product stewardship and safety, discharges to water and discharges of wastewater, noise and the generation, handling, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of chemicals and hazardous material and employee safety. We routinely incur costs in order to comply with these laws and regulations. Some of these environmental laws hold owners or operators of land or businesses liable for their own and for previous owners’ or operators’ releases of hazardous or toxic substances or wastes. Other environmental laws and regulations require us to obtain and comply with environmental permits.
