Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On July 3, 2021, Parent and Merger Sub, entities controlled by investment funds managed by BCP, entered into the Merger Agreement (which was subsequently amended on July 29, 2021) with the Company and the Equityholder Representative, solely in their capacity as such, pursuant to which Parent agreed to acquire the Company. The Acquisition is structured as a merger of Merger Sub with and into the Company, with the Company as the surviving entity. Upon the closing of the Acquisition, Parent will pay approximately $3.7 billion in cash, in the aggregate, to acquire the Company, including the estimated total cash consideration of $279.0 million to be paid for the acquisition of Brink, subject to certain adjustments. Completion of the Acquisition is subject to various conditions, including, among others, (i) approvals and/or termination or expiration of any applicable waiting periods (including any extensions thereof) under the HSR Act and under certain foreign antitrust laws or foreign direct investment laws, including the European Union, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, Brazil, France and Spain (ii) the absence of any order, or the enactment of any law, following the execution of the Merger Agreement prohibiting the Acquisition, (iii) subject to certain exceptions, the accuracy of the representations and warranties of the parties contained in the Merger Agreement and (iv) performance in all material respects by each party of its obligations under the Merger Agreement. The Merger Agreement contains customary representations, warranties and covenants of the parties thereto, including, among others, covenants (i) of the Company to use commercially reasonable efforts to, and cause its subsidiaries to use commercially reasonable efforts to, conduct their business and operations in the ordinary course in all material respects during the interim period between the execution of the Merger Agreement and completion of the Acquisition, (ii) of the Company not to engage in certain transactions during the interim period except with Parent’s written consent and (iii) of the parties to execute such documents and perform such further acts as may be reasonably required to carry out the provisions of the Merger Agreement and the actions contemplated thereby and use their reasonable best efforts to fulfill or obtain the fulfillment of the conditions precedent to consummate the transactions contemplated by the Merger Agreement. The Merger Agreement also contains certain termination rights for both the Company and Parent, including the right of either party to terminate the Merger Agreement if, other than in certain circumstances described therein, the Merger has not been consummated by April 15, 2022 and certain other conditions specified under the Merger Agreement are met. The Merger Agreement provides that, if any party to the Merger Agreement fails or refuses to perform any covenant or agreement, the non-breaching party will be entitled to specific performance of such covenant or agreement, subject to certain restrictions on the ability of the Company to seek specific performance to cause Parent and Merger Sub to draw down the equity financing. In addition, upon termination of the Merger Agreement under specified circumstances, Parent may be required to pay the Company a termination fee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global manufacturer and distributor of engineered components critical to the safety and performance of a range of towable and related applications. We deliver exceptional products that our customers rely on. We strive to deliver superior quality, provide the highest level of customer service and offer our customers innovative solutions through customized products and technology. We offer a broad portfolio of axle assemblies, hydraulic components, chassis, aftermarket parts, and other related engineered products. Our manufactured products span over 65,000 SKUs and are sold under a number of well-known, market-leading brands, including our flagship Dexter and AL-KO brands. We offer over 30,000 additional SKUs throughout our distribution network. We serve over 40,000 customers globally. Our manufactured products are used in applications across a diverse set of end-use segments, including agriculture, commercial, construction, general industrial, livestock, landscaping, marine, military, energy, residential, RV, transportation and many other specialty end-use segments. The majority of our products are critical to the reliability, safety and performance of the end-products in which they are utilized. Given the high cost of downtime relative to the cost of our products, our customers and the ultimate end-users of our products place a premium on the superior performance and reliability our products deliver. Our two flagship brands, Dexter in North America and AL-KO in the rest of the world, account for the majority of our sales. Our other brands, including CM Trailers, Kodiak, Redline, Redneck, Rockwell American, Silent Drive, Aguti, Bankside Patterson, CBE, E&P Hydraulics, Nordelettronica, Safim, Sawiko, G&S Chassis and upon consummation of the acquisition of Brink International B.V., Brink, are also recognized for product quality, reliability, innovation and superior customer service. The foregoing attributes, combined with our ability to deliver customized products with short lead times, have created deep and long-standing relationships with our customers. Our customer base is primarily made up of relatively small companies that lack engineering expertise in our product categories, thus we enjoy an advantaged position within a highly fragmented industry. Our advanced engineering expertise and proximity to our customers deeply ingrain us into our customers’ product design, engineering and development processes, enhance our longterm customer retention and support premium pricing for our products. We operate our business on a regional basis through our two reportable segments, North America and RoW. Within the majority of the end-use segments in which we compete, we estimate our sales are approximately five times larger than that of our next largest North American competitor and approximately three times larger than that of our largest European competitor. In addition, we believe that we have the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distributor of light and medium duty components for towable applications in North America. In 2020, 89% of our net sales were in end-use segments where we believe we hold the number one or number two position, based on management’s extensive knowledge and expertise in the industry. We believe that we are the primary axle provider to approximately two-thirds of our customers in North America and we are larger than the majority of our suppliers. Based on management’s knowledge of the industry, we believe that our scale, combined with our vertically integrated hub-and-spoke manufacturing and broad distribution network, enables us to respond to customer requests with premium quality customized product solutions, on shorter delivery lead times than many of our competitors and at an attractive cost position. 76 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We generated strong performance in 2020 and in the first half of 2021 despite being confronted with the significant macroeconomic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2020, compared to 2019, the Company increased net sales by $27.4 million, increased cash provided by operating activities by $26.0 million, increased cash and cash equivalents by $107.8 million and increased Adjusted EBITDA by $21.5 million. In the first half of 2021, compared to the same period of 2020, we increased net sales by $440.5 million, increased net income by $41.5 million and increased Adjusted EBITDA by $67.4 million. In the early part of the first quarter of 2020, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, we generated strong sales volumes and completed the acquisition of Silent Drive, which expanded our product offering of specialty heavy duty axles. As the first quarter of 2020 continued, it became clear that COVID-19 would have a significant impact on our revenues and operations. Our products are used in a wide array of industrial and utility trailers that are critical to end-user applications in numerous essential industries. While our facilities were generally able to continue operating as essential businesses, certain of our customers took significant unplanned downtime to adjust production and inventory levels to anticipated customer demand, causing our net sales during the second quarter of 2020 to decrease significantly compared to the same period in 2019. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and related volume declines, we immediately implemented an action plan focused on protecting the health of our employees, reducing costs and preserving liquidity given the macroeconomic uncertainty. Our first priority was to protect the health and safety of our employees by implementing our Preparedness and Response Plan, which included adjusting shift schedules to provide for social distancing, employee health surveys and temperature checks, enhanced cleaning of facilities and allowing our employees to continue to work remotely when possible. These measures continue to be in place. In North America, we significantly reduced costs by temporarily closing certain facilities, reducing our direct labor force, suspending our retirement plan contributions, reducing salaried workforce pay and implementing furloughs. Outside of North America, we implemented similar measures, as well as short-time work programs, often with the support of local governments. Throughout the world, we aggressively managed our working capital with significant reductions in accounts receivable and inventory levels. In the later part of the second quarter of 2020, end-consumer demand for recreational vehicles, boating and other outdoor activities drove rapidly increasing volumes for our products, particularly within recreational and light and medium duty industrial applications. End-consumer demand continued to strengthen through the remainder of 2020, resulting in record fourth quarter volumes. The increase in demand continued into the first half of 2021, which was bolstered by acquisitions and general market recovery. We responded by quickly increasing production to meet customer demand, while continuing to maintain our COVID-19 safety protocols. Despite record volumes and net sales, we continue to be impacted by strains on our supply chain that limit the availability and increase the cost of certain parts and materials and labor shortages related to the impact of COVID-19. Additionally, these changes in consumer behavior contributed to a slight negative mix impact to our gross margin. Despite challenges related to COVID-19, we continued to implement our M&A strategy and in the fourth quarter of 2020 completed the acquisition of Nordelettronica S.r.l., which expanded our offering of electronic components. At the beginning of 2021, we acquired Redneck Inc. and Redline Products LLC (together, “Redneck”), a leading distributor of trailer components in North America. Together with our Rockwell American distribution business, this acquisition creates what we believe to be the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distributor of light and medium duty components for towable applications in North America, provides us with unique insights into end-consumer behavior and preferences, and increases our aftermarket net sales.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: As a result of our global operations, we generate a significant portion of our net sales and incur a substantial portion of our expenses in currencies other than the U.S. dollar. As a result, our net sales, cost of goods sold, operating expenses and certain assets and liabilities fluctuate as the value of such currencies fluctuate in relation to 77 ----- the U.S. dollar. In addition, the results of operations of some of our operating entities are reported in currencies other than the U.S. dollar and then translated into U.S. dollars at the applicable exchange rate for inclusion in our financial statements. As a result, appreciation of the U.S. dollar against these other currencies generally will have a negative impact on our reported sales and profits while depreciation of the U.S. dollar against these other currencies will generally have a positive effect on reported sales and profits. Our primary currency exposures are the Euro, Australian dollar, British pound, Chinese renminbi and Canadian dollar. In addition, our Euro denominated debt, with a principal balance of €621.2 million as of June 30, 2021, is subject to translation gains and losses each period. We expect to have Euro denominated debt with a principal balance of approximately €950.0 million after completion of the Transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We have commodity price risk with respect to purchases of certain raw materials, including steel, rubber, oil and grease. Raw material, energy and commodity costs have been extremely volatile over the past several years. We have generally been able to adjust customer prices to recover commodity cost increases. As a result, our net sales and cost of goods sold may increase or decrease based on fluctuations in prevailing commodity prices during the period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our indebtedness contains variable interest rate provisions. As a result, our interest expense may vary from period to period due to variations in prevailing interest rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: In future periods, we expect to issue long-term equity incentive awards to our officers, key employees and nonemployees. The result will be an increase in our selling, general and administrative expenses in future periods as the grant-date value of the awards are recognized in expense over the vesting term of the awards.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Material Trends Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: In recent years, we have expanded our highly engineered product portfolio and geographic footprint, and have materially grown our addressable market through a series of acquisitions. In 2018, we acquired six businesses which collectively expanded our product portfolio to include hydraulic leveling solutions, air suspension and electronic components and wire harnesses and expanded our customer base and product offering in Australia and New Zealand. In 2019, we acquired five businesses, which collectively strengthened our chassis capabilities in the U.K. and Australia, provided entry into hydraulic components, strengthened our North American fender business and expanded our product portfolio to include seating systems for the European RV end-use segment. In 2020, we acquired two businesses, as well as the key strategic assets of another business, all of which strengthened our specialty heavy duty portfolio and grew our European electronic components business. In early 2021, we acquired a North American distribution business, which expanded our North American distribution footprint and substantially increased our aftermarket sales. In addition, in July 2021, a subsidiary of the Company entered into a purchase agreement to acquire Brink, a leading provider of towing and carrying solutions in Europe headquartered in Staphorst, Netherlands. Our results of operations include the impact of these acquisitions subsequent to the respective date of acquisition and as a result, periods prior to each of the acquisitions are not comparable to subsequent periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: To provide investors with additional information in connection with our results as determined by GAAP, we disclose Adjusted EBITDA and Leverageable EBITDA as a non-GAAP measures which management believes provide useful information to investors. Adjusted EBITDA and Leverageable EBITDA are not calculated in accordance with GAAP and should not be considered as substitutes for net income or any other operating performance measure calculated in accordance with GAAP, and may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies. We use Adjusted EBITDA to measure the operational strength and performance of our business. We use Leverageable EBITDA to measure liquidity. EBITDA is defined as net income (loss) before income tax expense (benefit), interest expense, net and depreciation and amortization. We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA adjusted for, among other things, (i) (gain) loss on foreign currency related to intercompany loans and foreign currency derivatives, (ii) restructuring expenses, (iii) share-based compensation, (iv) business optimization expenses, (v) sponsor management fees and (vi) acquisition and purchase accounting related items. Leverageable EBITDA is defined as Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to exclude certain items which we believe are not reflective of ongoing performance. We believe that the presentation of Adjusted EBITDA and Leverageable EBITDA is appropriate to provide additional information to investors about certain material non-cash items that we do not expect to continue at the same level in the future, as well as other items we do not consider indicative of our ongoing operating performance. Further, we believe Adjusted EBITDA and Leverageable EBITDA provide a meaningful measure of operating profitability because we use them for evaluating our business performance, making budgeting decisions, calculating incentive compensation for our employees, evaluating the performance and effectiveness of our operating strategies and in evaluating potential acquisitions. Leverageable EBITDA is also calculated in a manner consistent with the terms of the instruments that will govern our indebtedness.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Free Cash Flow is defined as Leverageable EBITDA less capital expenditures. We use Free Cash Flow to evaluate our ability to generate cash that can be used for working capital requirements, interest expense, repayment of indebtedness, financing new acquisitions and for continued re-investment in our business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We use various GAAP and non-GAAP financial metrics to analyze and evaluate the performance of our business and to provide a greater understanding with respect to our results of operations. These include Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow, which may not be comparable to similar measures used by other companies. Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow have important limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our financial performance as reported under GAAP and should not be considered as alternatives to net income or any other performance measures derived in accordance with GAAP as measures of operating performance or as alternatives to cash flow from operating activities as measures of our liquidity. 84 ----- Because of these limitations, Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business. We compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our GAAP results and using Adjusted EBITDA, Leverageable EBITDA and Free Cash Flow only for supplemental purposes. For a reconciliation of these metrics to the most directly comparable GAAP measure, see “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our principal liquidity requirements are to finance current operations, expenditures for property and equipment, debt service requirements and to support growth through acquisitions. These liquidity requirements are primarily funded by our cash flows from operations. To finance the Acquisition, we intend to issue the Notes offered hereby and, concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition, enter into (i) the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, initially consisting of (x) a 7-year $2,210.0 million equivalent principal amount New Term Loan Facility and (y) a 5-year $200.0 million New Revolving Facility and (ii) a 5-year $150.0 million New ABL Facility. We intend to use the proceeds of this offering and the borrowings under the New Term Loan Facility, together with equity contributions from funds affiliated with BCP and other investors (or limited partners of funds associated with either thereof), to (1) pay the cash consideration for the Acquisition and (2) pay related fees and expense. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Description of Certain Other Indebtedness.” 85 ----- Following the closing of this offering, we expect our ongoing sources of liquidity to include cash generated from operations, borrowings under our revolving credit facility and the future financing activities through capital market activities. Our future cash needs are expected to include cash for operating activities, working capital, capital expenditures, strategic investments, periodic principal and interest payments in relation to our debt, and potential future acquisitions. We believe our cash position, amounts available under our revolving credit facility, and cash provided by operating activities are and will continue to be adequate to meet our operational and business needs in the next twelve months as well as our long-term liquidity needs. Our ability to meet our debt service obligations and other capital requirements, including capital expenditures, as well as make acquisitions, will depend on our future operating performance which, in turn, will be subject to general economic, financial, business, competitive, regulatory and other conditions, many of which are beyond our control. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business.” As a normal part of our business, depending on market conditions, we will from time to time consider opportunities to repay or refinance our indebtedness. Changes in our operating plans, material changes in anticipated sales, increased expenses, acquisitions or other events may cause us to seek additional equity and/or debt financing in future periods. There can be no guarantee that financing will be available on acceptable terms or at all. Debt financing, if available, could impose additional cash payment obligations and additional covenants and operating restrictions. In addition, any of the items discussed in detail under the section titled “Risk Factors” may also significantly impact our liquidity.

[$ ] (158.5) $ 46.9 $ 107.8 $ (6.9) $ 40.6 86 |$ 323.7|Col2|$ 202.1| |---|---|---| ----- _Six Months Ended June 30, 2021 compared to the Six Months Ended June 30, 2020_ Cash provided by operating activities was $38.4 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021 compared to $79.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020. The decrease was primarily driven by higher working capital due to increased volume and higher material costs. Cash management strategies implemented by the Company in the quarter ended June 30, 2020 as a response to COVID-19 also contributed to the decrease, partially offset by higher cash earnings in the quarter ended June 30, 2021 due to increased sales. Cash used in investing activities was $186.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021 compared to $17.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020. The increase in cash used for investing activities was driven by increased cash paid for acquisitions. Cash used in financing activities was $9.7 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021 compared to $14.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020. The cash used in financing activities during 2021 was primarily related to recurring debt repayments, whereas cash used in 2020 was primarily related to recurring debt payments and payment of contingent consideration. _Year Ended December 31, 2020 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2019_ Cash provided by operating activities was $175.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to net cash used in operating activities of $149.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase was driven primarily by cash management strategies implemented by the Company, partially offset by lower cash earnings due to decreased volumes driven by the impact of COVID-19. Cash used in investing activities was $55.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to $322.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The decrease was driven by lower acquisition activity and reduced capital expenditures as a response to COVID-19. Cash used in financing activities was $22.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to net cash provided by financing activities of $166.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The cash used in financing activities during 2020 was primarily related to recurring debt repayments whereas financing proceeds were received in 2019 to fund an acquisition in addition to normal debt repayment activity. _Year Ended December 31, 2019 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2018_ Cash provided by operating activities was $149.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to $61.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase was driven primarily by higher cash earnings, increased collections on accounts receivable, and a decrease in inventory due to lower volumes in certain markets and optimization of inventory levels. Cash used in investing activities was $322.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to $158.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase in cash used for investing activities was driven by increased cash paid for acquisitions. Cash provided by financing activities was $166.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to net cash provided by financing activities of $141.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase was due to an increase in net borrowings, partially offset by the partial payment of contingent consideration and increased debt issuance costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Business combinations are accounted for under the acquisition method of accounting, which requires the recognition of assets acquired and liabilities assumed at their acquisition date fair values. The valuation of these assets and liabilities requires the use of estimates and judgment as to expectations for future cash flows of the acquired business, and the allocation of those cash flows to identifiable intangible assets. The fair value assigned to tangible and intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed are based on management’s estimates and assumptions, as well as other information compiled by management, including valuations that utilize customary valuation procedures and techniques. We generally engage third-party, independent valuation professionals to assist us in developing the assumptions and applying the valuation techniques to a particular business combination transaction. In particular, the discount rates selected are compared to and evaluated with (i) the industry weightedaverage cost of capital, (ii) the inherent risks associated with each type of asset and (iii) the level and timing of future cash flows appropriately reflecting market participant assumptions. Deferred taxes are recorded for any differences between the fair value and tax basis of assets acquired and liabilities assumed, and can vary based on the structure of the acquisition as to whether it is a taxable or non-taxable transaction. To the extent the purchase price of the acquired business exceeds the fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, including deferred income taxes recorded in connection with the transaction, such excess is recognized as goodwill.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill is evaluated for impairment annually or more often if a triggering event occurs between annual tests. The annual tests are performed as of October 1. In conducting our annual impairment testing, we may first perform a qualitative assessment of whether it is more likely than not that a reporting unit’s fair value is less than its carrying amount. If not, no further goodwill impairment testing is performed. If it is more likely than not that a reporting unit’s fair value is less than its carrying amount, or if we elect not to perform a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit, we then compare the fair value of the reporting unit to its carrying value. If the net book value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to that excess, limited to the total amount of goodwill allocated to that reporting unit. We have determined that we have three reporting units: North America, International Running Gear and Hydraulics. None of our reporting units are aggregated for purposes of the impairment test. Determination of our reporting units, impairment indicators and fair value requires us to make significant judgments and estimates, which are subject to a considerable degree of uncertainty. We utilize a third-party valuation specialist to assist in determining the fair value of our reporting units. Fair value of each reporting unit is estimated based on a combination of discounted cash flows and the use of pricing multiples derived from an analysis of comparable public companies multiplied against historical and/or anticipated financial metrics of each reporting unit. These calculations contain uncertainties as they require management to make assumptions including, but not limited to, market comparables, future cash flows of the reporting units, and appropriate discount and long-term growth rates. For the 2020 impairment test, we elected to perform a quantitative test for all of our reporting units. During our test, we determined that the estimated fair value of the North America reporting unit significantly exceeded its carrying value, the estimated fair value of the International Running Gear reporting unit exceeded its carrying value by approximately 6% and the estimated fair value of the Hydraulics reporting unit did not exceed its carrying value. 89 ----- As a result, an impairment charge for the entire goodwill balance of the Hydraulics reporting unit of $70.9 million was recorded. The impairment charge was the result of the impact of COVID-19 on the products, customer base, and geography of the Hydraulics reporting unit and declines in forecasted sales within that reporting unit. A decline in the actual cash flows of our International Running Gear reporting unit in future periods, compared to the projected cash flows used to calculate the estimated fair value, could result in the carrying value of this reporting unit exceeding its fair value. Further, a change in market comparables, discount rate or long-term growth rate, as a result of a change in economic conditions or otherwise, could result in the carrying value of our International Running Gear reporting unit exceeding its fair value, which would result in the impairment of some or all of the related goodwill attributed to this reporting unit. As of December 31, 2020, the goodwill balance attributed to the reporting units was $354.0 million for North America and $446.7 million for International Running Gear.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In determining the provision for income taxes for financial statement purposes, we make estimates and judgments that affect our evaluation of the carrying value of our deferred tax assets as well as our calculation of certain tax liabilities. We evaluate the carrying value of our deferred tax assets by considering all available positive and negative evidence. Such evidence includes historical operating results, the existence of cumulative earnings and losses in the most recent fiscal years, expectations for future pretax operating income, the time period over which our temporary differences will reverse, and the implementation of feasible and prudent tax planning strategies. Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if, based on the weight of this evidence, it is more likely than not that all or a portion of the recorded deferred tax assets will not be realized in future periods. In addition, the calculation of our tax benefits and liabilities includes uncertainties in the application of complex tax regulations in a multitude of jurisdictions across our global operations. We recognize tax benefits and liabilities based on our estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due. We adjust these liabilities based on changing facts and circumstances; however, due to the complexity of some of these uncertainties and the impact of any tax audits, the ultimate resolutions may be materially different from our estimated liabilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have obligations for retiree benefits for certain employees under defined benefit pension plans. For a description of these plans, see Note 16, “Employee Benefit Plans,” to the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. We use actuarial estimates and related actuarial methods to calculate our obligation and expense. We are required to select certain actuarial assumptions, which are determined based on current market conditions, historical information and consultation with and input from our actuaries. The key factors which impact our estimates are discount rates, asset return assumptions, compensation increase assumptions and actuarial assumptions such as retirement age and mortality which are determined as of the current year measurement date. We review our actuarial assumptions on an annual basis and make modifications to the assumptions based on current rates and trends when appropriate. These estimates and assumptions are subject to a considerable degree of uncertainty. To develop the discount rate for each pension plan, yield curves applicable to the plan’s country or region are applied to the expected cash flows underlying the plan’s benefit obligations to determine a single equivalent discount rate. The expected rate of return on plan assets assumption for the year is based on consideration of the respective target asset class allocations and the respective target asset class long-term return expectations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations is based upon our financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP. The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses. Certain of our accounting policies require the application of significant judgment by management in selecting the appropriate assumptions for calculating financial estimates. By their nature, these judgments are subject to an inherent degree of uncertainty. These judgments are based on our historical experience, terms of existing contracts, our evaluation of trends in the industry, information provided by our customers and information available from other outside sources, as appropriate. Our actual results may differ from these estimates. We consider an accounting estimate to be critical if it requires us to make assumptions about matters that were uncertain at the time we made the estimate and if changes in the estimate or different estimates that we could have selected could have had a material impact on our consolidated financial condition or results of operations. The accounting estimates 88 ----- that we believe to be the most critical to an understanding of our financial condition and results of operations and that require the most complex and subjective management judgments are discussed below. Our significant accounting policies are more fully described in Note 3, “Significant Accounting Policies,” to the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Accounting estimates and assumptions discussed in this section do not reflect a comprehensive list of all of our accounting policies, but are those that we consider to be the most critical to an understanding of the financial statements of the Company because they involve significant judgments and uncertainties.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: As a result of our global operations, we generate a significant portion of our sales and incur a substantial portion of our expenses in currencies other than the U.S. dollar. To the extent that we have significantly more costs than sales generated in a currency other than the U.S. dollar, we are subject to risk if the currency in which our costs are paid appreciates against the currency in which we generate sales because the appreciation effectively increases our cost in that country. We may selectively enter into forward foreign currency exchange contracts to reduce our foreign currency exchange risk. We did not have any forward foreign currency exchange contracts outstanding as of December 31, 2020. The financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of some of our operating entities are reported in currencies other than the U.S. dollar and then translated into U.S. dollars at the applicable exchange rate for inclusion in our financial statements. As a result, appreciation of the U.S. dollar against these other currencies generally will have a negative impact on our reported sales and profits while depreciation of the U.S. dollar against these other currencies will generally have a positive effect on reported sales and profits. Our primary exposure is to fluctuations in the Euro exchange rate, and we also have exposure to fluctuations in other currency exchange rates, including the Australian dollar, British pound, Chinese renminbi and Canadian dollar. The following table sets forth a sensitivity analysis of the effect a hypothetical change in the Euro to U.S. dollar exchange rate would have on our net sales and the carrying value of our Euro denominated debt for the year ended and as of December 31, 2020:

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates and commodity prices for products we use in our manufacturing process. We actively manage our exposure to risk from changes in foreign currency exchange rates and interest rates through the use of derivative financial instruments in accordance with management’s guidelines. We do not enter into derivative instruments for trading or speculative purposes. 90 ----- Additional information regarding these financial instruments can be found in Note 14, “Derivatives,” to the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following information should be read together with the information under the headings “Capitalization” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and our financial statements and related notes included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations contains forward-looking statements and involves numerous risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, those set forth under “Recent Developments— COVID-19,” “Risk Factors” and “Cautionary Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.” Actual results may differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statement._

We are a leading global manufacturer and distributor of engineered components critical to the safety and performance of a range of towable and related applications. We deliver exceptional products that our customers rely on. We strive to deliver superior quality, provide the highest level of customer service and offer our customers innovative solutions through customized products and technology. We offer a broad portfolio of axle assemblies, hydraulic components, chassis, aftermarket parts, and other related engineered products. Our manufactured products span over 65,000 SKUs and are sold under a number of well-known, market-leading brands, including our flagship Dexter and AL-KO brands. We offer over 30,000 additional SKUs throughout our distribution network. We serve over 40,000 customers globally. Our manufactured products are used in applications across a diverse set of end-use segments, including agriculture, commercial, construction, general industrial, livestock, landscaping, marine, military, energy, residential, RV, transportation and many other specialty end-use segments. The majority of our products are critical to the reliability, safety and performance of the end-products in which they are utilized. Given the high cost of downtime relative to the cost of our products, our customers and the ultimate end-users of our products place a premium on the superior performance and reliability our products deliver. Our two flagship brands, Dexter in North America and AL-KO in the rest of the world, account for the majority of our sales. Our other brands, including CM Trailers, Kodiak, Redline, Redneck, Rockwell American, Silent Drive, Aguti, Bankside Patterson, CBE, E&P Hydraulics, Nordelettronica, Safim, Sawiko, G&S Chassis and upon consummation of the acquisition of Brink International B.V., Brink, are also recognized for product quality, reliability, innovation and superior customer service. The foregoing attributes, combined with our ability to deliver customized products with short lead times, have created deep and long-standing relationships with our customers. Our customer base is primarily made up of relatively small companies that lack engineering expertise in our product categories, thus we enjoy an advantaged position within a highly fragmented industry. Our advanced engineering expertise and proximity to our customers deeply ingrain us into our customers’ product design, engineering and development processes, enhance our longterm customer retention and support premium pricing for our products. We operate our business on a regional basis through our two reportable segments, North America and RoW. Within the majority of the end-use segments in which we compete, we estimate our sales are approximately five times larger than that of our next largest North American competitor and approximately three times larger than that of our largest European competitor. In addition, we believe that we have the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distributor of light and medium duty components for towable applications in North America. In 2020, 89% of our net sales were in end-use segments where we believe we hold the number one or number two position, based on management’s extensive knowledge and expertise in the industry. We believe that we are the primary axle provider to approximately two-thirds of our customers in North America and we are larger than the majority of our suppliers. Based on management’s knowledge of the industry, we believe that our scale, combined with our vertically integrated hub-and-spoke manufacturing and broad distribution network, enables us to respond to customer requests with premium quality customized product solutions, on shorter delivery lead times than many of our competitors and at an attractive cost position. 92 -----

Industrial and Utility(2) 47% (1) Rest of World 44% Components and other 46% Axle and Chassis 54% North America 56% Other 14% Aftermarket 15% Recreation 24% Note: Business breakdown based on 2020 Net Sales. (1) Rest of World includes Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom, Spain, France, Australia and several other countries. (2) Industrial & Utility includes Agriculture, Commercial, Construction, DIY, Energy, Transportation, Military and Specialty Heavy Duty. In January 2021, we acquired Redneck, a leading distributor of trailer components in North America. Together with our Rockwell American distribution business, this acquisition creates what we believe to be the broadest geographic footprint of any single aftermarket distributor of light and medium duty components for towable applications in North America, provides us with unique insights into end-consumer behavior and preferences, and increases our aftermarket net sales. Our strong brand reputation and growing installed base allow us to capture high margin aftermarket business. In 2020, aftermarket net sales as a percentage of consolidated net sales would have increased from 15% to approximately 20% if Redneck sales were included. In July 2021, we reached an agreement to acquire the European towbar solutions specialist Brink International B.V., which expands our portfolio into the area of engineered towing and carrying solutions. Brink enjoys a global manufacturing footprint and long-term exclusive relationships with major OEs, with a strong focus on performance, safety standards, availability and innovation. Approximately 73% of Brink’s 2020 net sales are from retrofit and 27% from line fit. Brink’s difficult to replicate product offerings and large SKU availability drives its leading position in the aftermarket. We believe compelling underlying trends will support future growth with increasing Brink towbar take rates, growing share of SUVs, increased consumer interest in towing products and low towbar share penetration of existing vehicles. We have consistently delivered strong financial and operating results. For the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, we generated net sales of $1,534.0 million and $1,506.6 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $268.5 million and $247.0 million, respectively. For the trailing twelve months ended June 30, 2021, we generated net sales of $2,252.0 million and Leverageable EBITDA of $380.2 million, pro forma for the acquisition of Brink and the Transactions. 93 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS New Senior Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: Amounts borrowed under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities are expected to be subject to interest at a rate per annum equal to an applicable margin plus, at our option, either (a) for base rate loans denominated in US Dollars, a base rate determined by reference to the highest of (i) the rate last quoted by The Wall Street Journal (or, if such rate is not quoted by The Wall Street Journal, another national publication selected by the administrative agent in consultation with the Lead Borrower) as the U.S. “Prime Rate” in effect on such day, (ii) the Federal Funds Effective Rate plus 0.50% per annum and (iii) the one month US Dollar LIBOR rate (which shall not be less than 0.50% in the case of of US-denominated term loans and not less than 0.00% in the case of Euro-denominated term loans and revolving loans) plus 1.00% per annum, (b) for Eurodollar rate loans denominated in US Dollars or Euros, a rate determined by reference to the highest of (i) the US Dollar LIBOR rate (in the case of the US Dollardenominated loans) or the EURIBOR rate (in the case of the Euro-denominated loans) based on the interest rate of the applicable borrowing and (ii) 0.00% (or 0.50% in the case of US Dollar denominated term loans), (c) for revolving loans denominated in Canadian dollars, the rate equal to the Canadian Dollar Offered Rate (“CDOR”), as published on the applicable Reuters screen page (or such other commercially available source providing such quotations as may be designated by the administrative agent from time to time) on the day which is two business days prior to the first day of the interest period of the applicable borrowing with a term equivalent to such interest period (or, if such rate is unavailable, the highest of (i) the interest rate publicly announced from time to time by the administrative agent as its reference rate in effect on such day at its principal office in Toronto for determining interest rates applicable to commercial loans denominated in Canadian dollars and made by it in Canada (each 113 ----- change in such reference rate being effective from and including the date such change is publicly announced as being effective) and (ii) the interest rate per annum equal to the sum of (x) the rate that appears on the Reuters Screen CDOR Page for Canadian dollar bankers’ acceptances having a term of one month on the date of determination as reported by the administrative agent (and if such screen is not available, any successor or similar service as may be reasonably selected by the administrative agent) and (y) 1.00% per annum (the “Canadian Prime Rate”)), (d) for loans denominated in Australian dollars, the rate equal to the Bank Bill Swap Reference Bid Rate (“BBSY”), as published on the applicable Reuters screen page (or such other commercially available source providing such quotations as may be designated by the administrative agent from time to time) on the day which is two business days prior to the first day of the interest period of the applicable borrowing with a term equivalent to such interest period or (e) in the case of loans denominated in British pound sterling, the rate equal to the Sterling Overnight Index Average (“SONIA”) for a business day published by the SONIA Administrator on the SONIA Administrator’s Website on the immediately succeeding business day. New Revolving Facility loans denominated in other currencies will be subject to interest at a rate per annum equal to an applicable margin plus the customary equivalent to the Eurodollar rate. We expect to be required to pay (a) an unused line fee to the lenders under the New Revolving Facility on the committed but unutilized balance of the New Revolving Facility at a rate of, initially, 0.50% per annum, subject to stepdowns upon the achievement of certain first lien net leverage ratios and (b) a ticking fee to the lenders under the Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility on the committed but unutilized balance of the Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility at a rate of (x) 50% of the applicable margin for Eurodollar rate loans under the new Senior Secured Credit Facilities from the date that is 61 days to 180 days after the closing of the Acquisition and (y) 100% of the applicable margin for Eurodollar rate loans under the new Senior Secured Credit Facilities from the date that is 181 days after the closing of the Acquisition until the earlier of (i) the voluntary termination of all commitments under the Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility, (ii) the funding of all term loans under the Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility and (iii) the automatic expiration of commitments under the Delayed Draw Term Loan Facility on the second anniversary of the Closing Date.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS New Senior Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: The definitive loan documents that will govern the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities is expected to require us to prepay outstanding term loans, subject to certain exceptions, with: (1) 100% of the net cash proceeds of any incurrence of debt not permitted under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and debt incurred to refinance the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, (2) 50% (which percentage will be reduced to 25% and 0% if our first lien net leverage ratio is less than specified levels) of our annual excess cash flow (as defined in the credit agreement that will govern the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities) minus the amount of any voluntary prepayments of first lien term loans and certain other debt, and any voluntary prepayment of certain first lien revolving facilities to the extent such prepayment is accompanied by a permanent commitment reduction, in each case made (or committed to be made) during the applicable calculation period (or, at the Lead Borrower’s option, after the applicable calculation period and prior to the payment due date) and further reduced by certain other amounts and (3) 100% (which percentage will be reduced to 50% and 0% if our first lien net leverage ratio is less than specified levels) of the net cash proceeds of asset sales or other dispositions of assets constituting collateral pursuant to the “unlimited” basket (and including non-ordinary course casualty or condemnation events with respect to assets constituting collateral) by the Lead Borrower or by any guarantor, subject to reinvestment rights and certain other exceptions. Mandatory repayments will be applied pro rata across the term loans, subject to certain exceptions.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS New Senior Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: We expect to be able to voluntarily prepay outstanding loans under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities at any time without premium or penalty, other than (i) customary “breakage” costs and (ii) a premium of 1.00% applicable to any prepayment of the New Term Loan Facility that is made in connection with a “repricing transaction” (subject to certain exceptions) that occurs on or prior to the 6-month anniversary of the effective date of the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities. 114 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS New Senior Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: The New USD Term Loan is expected to amortize at 1% per annum in equal quarterly installments, with the balance payable at the time the New Term Loan Facility matures in 2028. The New Euro Term Loan is not expected to amortize. The New Revolving Facility will not amortize and will mature in 2026.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS New Senior Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: Certain of our direct and indirect wholly-owned subsidiaries (and, at our option, other subsidiaries of the Lead Borrower) are expected to unconditionally guarantee all obligations under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities (with certain agreed-upon exceptions). All obligations under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, and the guarantees of those obligations, are expected to be secured, subject to certain exceptions, by: - a pledge of 100% of the equity interests of the Lead Borrower and certain of the equity interests held by the Lead Borrower or any guarantor subsidiary; and - a security interest in substantially all other tangible and intangible assets of Holdings, the Lead Borrower and each guarantor subsidiary, subject to certain permitted liens and customary exceptions. The liens securing our obligations under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities are expected to be second priority liens on the “borrowing base” (and certain other) assets securing the New ABL Facility and first priority liens on the other relevant assets of Holdings, the Lead Borrower and the guarantor subsidiaries, subject to customary exceptions and liens permitted under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS New Senior Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Title: Certain Covenants and Events of Default
Subsubsection Text: The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities are expected to contain a number of covenants that, among other things and subject to certain exceptions, restrict the ability of the Lead Borrower and its restricted subsidiaries to, among other things: - incur additional indebtedness, including capital leases; - pay dividends on capital stock or redeem, repurchase or retire capital stock or certain indebtedness; - make investments, loans, advances and acquisitions; - enter into agreements with negative pledge clauses; - engage in transactions with our affiliates; - sell or dispose of assets, including the capital stock of our subsidiaries; - make certain fundamental changes, including consolidate or merge; and - create liens. The credit agreement that will govern the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities is also expected to contain a customary passive holding company covenant applicable to Holdings and a leverage-based financial maintenance covenant, applicable only to the New Revolving Facility and only applicable if certain exposures thereunder exceed a threshold amount on the last day of a fiscal quarter. The credit agreement that will govern the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities is also expected to contain certain events of default, including payment defaults, failure to perform or observe covenants, cross-defaults with certain other events of default in connection with our other material indebtedness, a change of control and certain bankruptcy events, among others. 115 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS New Senior Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition, we intend to enter into a first lien syndicated facility credit agreement with, among others, Dexko Global Inc., a Delaware corporation (the “Lead Borrower”), as lead borrower, AL-KO Vehicle Technology Group Gmbh, a German limited liability company (Gesellschaft mit beschränkter _Haftung) registered in the commercial register (Handelsregister) of the local court (Amtsgericht) of Memmingen_ under HRB 18373 (the “German Borrower”), as German borrower, Dragon Acquisition Intermediate Holdco, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (“Holdings”), as holding company guarantor, Credit Suisse AG, Cayman Islands Branch, as administrative agent and collateral agent, and the lenders party thereto, providing for the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities described under the heading “The Transactions—Acquisition Financing Transactions.” The final terms of the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities may not be determined until after completion of this offering and may differ from those described below. Under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, we expect to have the ability to increase the amount of term loans and/or revolving credit facilities thereunder, or incur incremental equivalent debt, in an aggregate amount not to exceed (a) a “fixed” amount set at the greater of $380 million and 100% of consolidated EBITDA on a trailing four quarter basis plus (b) an additional amount subject to (i) if such indebtedness is secured by a lien on the collateral that is pari passu with the lien on the collateral securing the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, the pro forma first lien net leverage ratio not exceeding the greater of (1) the ratio that is 0.25x above the first lien net leverage ratio on the Closing Date and (2) the first lien net leverage ratio immediately prior to the incurrence of such indebtedness, (ii) if such indebtedness is secured by a lien on the collateral that is junior to the lien on the collateral securing the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, either (x) the pro forma secured net leverage ratio not exceeding the greater of (1) the ratio that is 0.50x above the secured net leverage ratio on the Closing Date and (2) the secured net leverage ratio immediately prior to the incurrence of such indebtedness or (y) the interest coverage ratio not being less than the lesser of (1) 1.75 to 1.00 and (2) the pro forma interest coverage ratio immediately prior to the incurrence of such indebtedness or (iii) if such indebtedness is unsecured or secured by assets that do not secure the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, either (x) the pro forma total net leverage ratio not exceeding the greater of (1) the ratio that is 0.75x above the total net leverage ratio on the Closing Date and (2) the total net leverage ratio immediately prior to the incurrence of such indebtedness or (y) the interest coverage ratio not being less than the lesser of (1) 1.75 to 1.00 and (2) the interest coverage ratio immediately prior to the incurrence of such indebtedness plus (c) other “fixed” dollar amounts that may be reallocated to increase the amount of term loans and/or revolving credit facilities, as well as customary prepayment builder amounts. The lenders under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities will not be under any obligation to provide commitments in respect of any such increase or incurrence.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition, we intend to enter into a credit agreement with, among others, the Lead Borrower, the German Borrower, each of the other borrowers from time to time party thereto, Holdings, as holding company guarantor, Bank of Montreal, as administrative agent and collateral agent, and the lenders and issuing banks party thereto, for an asset-based revolving credit facility (the “New ABL Facility”) which will allow us to draw up to $150.0 million, subject to borrowing base availability, and will mature in 2026. At least $35.0 million is expected to be available for the issuance of letters of credit. Under the New ABL Facility, we expect to have the ability to increase the amount of revolving commitments outstanding thereunder by $100.0 million and certain other amounts. The lenders under the New ABL Facility will not be under any obligation to provide commitments in respect of any such increase. The final terms of the New ABL Facility may not be determined until after completion of this offering and may differ from those described above and below. Amounts borrowed under the New ABL Facility are expected to be subject to interest at a rate per annum equal to an applicable margin plus, at our option, either (a) for base rate loans denominated in US Dollars, a base rate determined by reference to the highest of (i) the rate last quoted by The Wall Street Journal (or, if such rate is not quoted by The Wall Street Journal, another national publication selected by the administrative agent in consultation with the Lead Borrower) as the U.S. “Prime Rate” in effect on such day, (ii) the Federal Funds Effective Rate plus 0.50% per annum and (iii) the one month US Dollar LIBOR rate (which shall not be less than 0.00%) plus 1.00% per annum, (b) for Eurodollar rate loans denominated in US Dollars or Euros, a rate determined by reference to the highest of (i) the US Dollar LIBOR rate (in the case of US Dollar denominated loans) or the EURIBOR rate (in the case of Euro denominated loans) based on the interest period of the applicable borrowing and (ii) 0.00%, (c) for loans denominated in Canadian dollars, the rate equal to CDOR (or, if such rate is unavailable, the Canadian Prime Rate), (d) for loans denominated in Australian dollars, the rate equal to BBSY or (e) in the case of loans denominated in British pound sterling, the rate equal to SONIA. Asset-based revolving loans denominated in other currencies will be subject to interest at a rate per annum equal to an applicable margin plus the customary equivalent to the Eurodollar rate. The applicable margin percentage for asset-based revolving loans is expected to be a percentage per annum and ranges from 0.25% to 0.75% for base rate and Canadian Prime Rate loans and 1.25% to 1.75% for BBSY, Eurodollar and SONIA rate loans. The applicable margin percentages with respect to borrowings under the New ABL Facility are expected to be subject to adjustments based on historical excess availability as defined in the credit agreement for the New ABL Facility. We also expect to be required to pay an unused line fee to the lenders under the New ABL Facility on the committed but unutilized balance of the New ABL Facility at a rate of 0.375% or 0.250% per annum, which varies depending on utilization. The New ABL Facility is expected to contain customary covenants and restrictions that, among other things and subject to certain exceptions, restrict the ability of the borrowers and their restricted subsidiaries to, among others: - incur additional indebtedness, including capital leases; - pay dividends on capital stock or redeem, repurchase or retire capital stock or certain indebtedness; - make investments, loans, advances and acquisitions; - enter into agreements with negative pledge clauses; - engage in transactions with our affiliates; - sell or dispose of assets, including the capital stock of our subsidiaries; - make certain fundamental changes, including consolidate or merge; and - create liens. The credit agreement that will govern the New ABL Facility is also expected to contain a customary passive holding company covenant applicable to Holdings. 116 ----- The New ABL Facility is expected to require us to maintain a fixed-charge coverage ratio of at least 1.0 to 1.0 if Specified Availability (as defined below and to be more particularly defined in the credit agreement that will govern the New ABL Facility) is less than the greater of (i) 10% of the maximum amount that can be borrowed under the New ABL Facility, based on the lesser of the borrowing base and the aggregate commitments under the New ABL Facility at such time (the “Line Cap”) and (ii) $7.5 million. “Specified Availability” is the sum of (i) the amount by which the Line Cap exceeds the total exposure under the New ABL Facility at such time plus (ii) the amount (if any, and not to be less than zero or exceed 5% of the aggregate commitments under the New ABL Facility) by which the borrowing base at such time exceeds the aggregate commitments under the New ABL Facility. Certain of our direct and indirect wholly-owned subsidiaries may be co-borrowers under the New ABL Facility. Such obligations are also expected to be unconditionally guaranteed by Holdings and each of the Lead Borrower’s other direct and indirect wholly-owned subsidiaries (with certain agreed-upon exceptions). All obligations under the New ABL Facility, and the guarantees of those obligations, are expected to be secured by first priority liens on the “borrowing base” assets, including accounts receivables and other receivables (other than identifiable proceeds of certain collateral), cash and cash equivalents and securities and deposit accounts (with certain agreed-upon exceptions), chattel paper, inventory, and rights, documents and general intangibles relating to the foregoing (excluding, for the avoidance of doubt, trademarks, trade names and other intellectual property), insurance, instruments and books and records relating thereto and proceeds of the foregoing and second priority liens on the other relevant assets of Holdings, the co-borrowers and the guarantor subsidiaries, subject to customary exceptions and liens permitted under the New ABL Facility. The credit agreement that will govern the New ABL Facility is also expected to contain certain events of default, including payment defaults, failure to perform or observe covenants, cross-defaults with other events of default in connection with our other material indebtedness, a change of control and certain bankruptcy events, among others. The available borrowing capacity under the New ABL Facility will vary monthly according to the levels of our eligible accounts receivables, eligible unbilled receivables, eligible inventory and certain qualified cash and the amount of any reserves imposed by the administrative agent. In addition, there will be no ability to borrow during a default or an event of default. 117 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: Certain terms used in this description are defined under the subheading “—Certain Definitions.” In this description, (1) the term “Issuer” refers to Dornoch Debt Merger Sub Inc., a Delaware corporation, prior to the Escrow Release Date and DexKo Global Inc., a Delaware corporation, from and after the Escrow Release Date, and not to any of its Subsidiaries or Affiliates; (2) the term “Holdings” refers to BCP Dornoch Parent Inc., a Delaware corporation, prior to the Escrow Release Date and Dragon Acquisition Intermediate Holdco, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company, from and after the Escrow Release Date (and its successors in interest pursuant to the definition of “Holdings” set forth under “Certain Definitions”), and not to any of their Subsidiaries; and (3) the terms “we,” “our” and “us” each refer to the Issuer and its consolidated Subsidiaries. The Issuer will issue $665,000,000 aggregate principal amount of   % senior notes due 2029 (the “Notes”) under an indenture (the “Indenture”), to be dated as of the Issue Date, among the Issuer and Deutsche Bank Trust Company Americas, as trustee (the “Trustee”), registrar (the “Registrar”), Paying Agent (as defined herein) and transfer agent (the “Transfer Agent”). The Notes will be issued in a private transaction that is not subject to the registration requirements of the Securities Act. See “Transfer Restrictions.” The Issuer will not be required to, nor does it currently intend to, offer to exchange the Notes for notes registered under the Securities Act or otherwise register or qualify by prospectus the Notes for resale under the Securities Act or the state securities laws or under the securities laws of any other non-U.S. jurisdiction. The Indenture will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended, or subject to the terms thereof. Accordingly, the terms of the Notes include only those stated in the Indenture. The Issuer does not intend to list the Notes on any securities exchange or for inclusion of the Notes in any automated quotation system. The closing of this offering of the Notes may occur prior to the Completion Date. In that case, pending the satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, the gross proceeds of the offering of the Notes will be placed in a segregated escrow account (the “Escrow Account”). If the Escrow Release Conditions are not satisfied on or prior to the Escrow End Date (as defined below) (or such earlier date as the Issuer notifies the Trustee and the Escrow Agent (as defined below) in writing that either (x) in its reasonable judgment the Acquisition will not be consummated on or prior to the Escrow End Date or (y) the Merger Agreement (as defined below) has been terminated), then the Notes offered hereby will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption at a redemption price of 100% of the issue price of the Notes offered hereby, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but not including, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined below). See “—Escrow of Gross Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” The funds in the Escrow Account will be released and applied to pay for any such redemption and any unpaid fees or expenses of the Escrow Agent and the Trustee, with any excess amounts to be released to the Issuer. If the closing of this offering of the Notes occurs on the Completion Date, the escrow provisions set forth in this description will not be applicable. The following description is only a summary of the material provisions of the Indenture and the Escrow Agreement. It does not purport to be complete and is qualified in its entirety by reference to the provisions of the Indenture and the Escrow Agreement, including the definitions therein of certain terms used below. We urge you to read the Indenture and the Escrow Agreement because they, and not this description, will define your rights as Holders of the Notes. You may request copies of the Indenture and the Escrow Agreement as set forth under “Where You Can Find Additional Information.”

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: Prior to the Escrow Release Date (if the Escrow Release Conditions are not satisfied on or prior to the Issue Date), the Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer secured by a first-priority security interest in the Escrow Account and all amounts on deposit therein. From and after the Completion Date, the Notes will be: - general, unsecured senior obligations of the Issuer; - equal in right of payment with any existing and future Senior Indebtedness of the Issuer; 118 ----- - effectively subordinated to any existing or future Secured Indebtedness of the Issuer to the extent of the value of the collateral securing such Secured Indebtedness, including Secured Indebtedness outstanding under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New ABL Facility; - senior in right of payment to any future Indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; and - structurally subordinated to all existing and future Indebtedness and other liabilities of the Issuer’s Subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: Prior to the Escrow Release Date (if the Escrow Release Conditions are not satisfied on or prior to the Issue Date), the Notes will be guaranteed only by Holdings. From and after the Completion Date, Holdings and certain of the Issuer’s Restricted Subsidiaries (as detailed below) will guarantee the Notes. The Issuer’s existing or future Foreign Subsidiaries, existing or future FSHCO Subsidiaries and any future Receivables Subsidiaries are not expected to guarantee the Notes. The Guarantors, as primary obligors and not merely as sureties, will jointly and severally guarantee, fully and unconditionally, on a senior unsecured basis, the performance and full and punctual payment when due, whether at maturity, by acceleration or otherwise, of all obligations of the Issuer under the Indenture and the Notes, whether for payment of principal of, premium, if any, or interest on, the Notes or expenses, indemnification or otherwise, on the terms set forth in the Indenture by executing the Indenture or a supplement thereto. As further described in “—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Guarantees of Indebtedness by Restricted Subsidiaries,” in the future, certain additional Restricted Subsidiaries of the Issuer that guarantee certain Indebtedness of the Issuer or any Guarantor will guarantee the Notes, subject to certain exceptions and subject to release and discharge as described in this “Description of Notes.” Each of the Guarantees will be: - a general, unsecured senior obligation of such Guarantor; - equal in right of payment with any existing and future Senior Indebtedness of such Guarantor; - effectively subordinated to any existing and future Secured Indebtedness of such Guarantor to the extent of the collateral securing such Secured Indebtedness; - senior in right of payment to any future Indebtedness of such Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Guarantee of such Guarantor; - structurally subordinated to all existing and future Indebtedness, claims of holders of Preferred Stock and other liabilities of the Issuer or such Guarantor’s Subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes (other than the Issuer); and - subordinated to obligations prescribed by statute, such as tax, social security and labor. As of June 30, 2021, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions: - the Issuer and the Guarantors would have had $2,595.0 million in long-term indebtedness outstanding, $1,930.0 million of which would have been senior secured indebtedness outstanding under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities; and 119 ----- - the Issuer would have had availability to incur additional secured indebtedness of $200.0 million under the revolving credit facility under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and $150.0 million under the New ABL Facility (in each case reduced by the amount of borrowings of loans and any letters of credit to be issued under such facilities on the Completion Date), subject to satisfaction of customary borrowing conditions (including borrowing base availability in the case of the New ABL Facility). After giving pro forma effect to the Transactions, a portion of the amounts outstanding under the Euro denominated tranche of the New Senior Secured Facilities will be incurred by and/or guaranteed by non-U.S. subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Notes, and as a result holders of the Notes will be structurally junior to those obligations. The obligations of the Issuer and the Restricted Subsidiaries under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New ABL Facility will be (i) effectively senior to the Notes to the extent of the collateral securing such obligations and (ii) structurally senior to the Notes with respect to the liabilities of the foreign Restricted Subsidiaries under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the New ABL Facility that guarantee such Indebtedness that do not guarantee the Notes. From and after the Completion Date, unless designated as Unrestricted Subsidiaries in accordance with the Indenture, all of the Issuer’s Subsidiaries will be “Restricted Subsidiaries.” Under certain circumstances, we will be permitted to designate certain of our existing and future subsidiaries as “Unrestricted Subsidiaries.” Any Unrestricted Subsidiaries will not be subject to any of the restrictive covenants in the Indenture and will not guarantee the Notes. As of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020, before intercompany eliminations, the non-Guarantor Subsidiaries represented approximately 33.2% and 33.0% of our revenues, 32.1% and 27.4% of our Adjusted EBITDA and 22.1% and 22.2% of our total assets (excluding cash) of the Company, respectively.
