Subsection Title: Management’s Responsibility for the Interim Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The Company’s management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the interim financial information in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America; this responsibility includes the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control sufficient to provide a reasonable basis for the preparation and fair presentation of interim financial information in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.

Our responsibility is to conduct our reviews in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America applicable to reviews of interim financial information. A review of interim financial information consists principally of applying analytical procedures and making inquiries of persons responsible for financial and accounting matters. It is substantially less in scope than an audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America, the objective of which is the expression of an opinion regarding the financial information. Accordingly, we do not express such an opinion.

Based on our reviews, we are not aware of any material modifications that should be made to the interim financial information referred to above for it to be in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.

Subsection Title: Report on Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet as of December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: We have previously audited, in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America, the consolidated balance sheet of the Company as of December 31, 2020, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income (loss), stockholders' equity, and cash flows for the year then ended (not presented herein); and we expressed an unmodified audit opinion on those audited consolidated financial statements in our report dated March 26, 2021. In our opinion, the accompanying condensed consolidated balance sheet of the Company as of December 31, 2020, is consistent, in all material respects, with the audited consolidated financial statements from which it has been derived. DexKo Global Holdings Inc. (“DexKo Holdings”) is the parent company of DexKo Global Inc. (“DexKo” or the “Company”). DexKo is a leading global manufacturer and distributor of engineered components critical to the safety and performance of a range of towable and related applications. DexKo offers a broad portfolio of axle assemblies, hydraulic components, chassis, aftermarket parts and other related engineered products. The accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”) for interim financial reporting. Accordingly, they do not include all of the information and footnotes required by U.S. GAAP for complete financial statements. These financial statements include all adjustments (consisting of normal, recurring adjustments) considered necessary for a fair presentation of the financial position and results of operations of the Company. The operating results for the interim period ended June 30, 2021 are not necessarily indicative of results that may be expected for any other interim period or for the full year. The accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements and notes thereto should be read in conjunction with the audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020.

On January 19, 2021, the Company purchased all the issued and outstanding shares of Redneck Inc. and Redline Products, LLC (together, “Redneck”) at a purchase price of $175.1 million, subject to customary adjustments. The acquisition of Redneck further extends the Company’s United States distribution footprint, increases its aftermarket sales and diversifies its customer portfolio. The acquisition was accounted for as a business combination using the acquisition method of accounting. The Company recorded $5.4 million of acquisition costs in connection with the acquisition. The pro forma effect of this acquisition would not materially impact the Company’s reported results for any period presented, either individually or in the aggregate for each period presented in the condensed consolidated statements of operations. As a result, no pro forma information has been presented. Additionally, the revenue and earnings of the entity acquired during the six months ended June 30, 2021 since the date of acquisition did not materially impact the Company’s reported results. In conjunction with the acquisition, the Company preliminarily recognized $31.2 million of goodwill in the North America segment, which is primarily attributable to the assembled workforce and expected synergies from combining operations. The Company expects the goodwill to be deductible for tax purposes. The following table summarizes the preliminary allocation of the purchase price consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as of the acquisition date: Cash and cash equivalents $ 7.6 Accounts receivable 10.0 Inventories 27.8 Prepaid expenses and other current assets 1.2 Property, plant and equipment 9.9 Intangible assets 97.1 Goodwill 31.2 Operating lease assets 12.2 Other assets 0.6 Total assets acquired 197.6 Accounts payable 7.1 Accrued liabilities and other 4.9 Income tax payable 0.1 Operating lease liabilities 10.4 Total liabilities assumed 22.5 Net assets acquired $ 175.1 Intangible assets acquired consist of $56.4 million of customer relationships and $40.7 million of tradenames and trademarks with a weighted average amortization period of 13 years. The preliminary allocation of the purchase price to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, including the residual amount recognized as goodwill, is based upon estimated information and is subject to change within the measurement period. Measurement period adjustments are recorded in the period identified with an offsetting entry to goodwill. The primary areas of the preliminary purchase price allocation that are not yet finalized relate to certain current assets, current liabilities, deferred income taxes, property, plant and equipment, and intangible assets. The fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed are based on our preliminary estimates and assumptions. We will continue to evaluate available information prior to the finalization of the amounts. -----

The Company incurs restructuring expenses in connection with its ongoing integration of completed business acquisitions and its focus on creating a more streamlined organization to reduce costs and prepare for future growth. The Company’s restructuring activities primarily include the closure or consolidation of facilities and the reorganization of its operating structure. The Company’s restructuring charges consist of employee separation costs, facility closure costs and other exit costs such as contract termination costs, fixed asset impairment charges and equipment and personnel relocation costs. The Company expects to incur a total of approximately $6.6 million of restructuring costs related to its restructuring plans that were not substantially complete as of June 30, 2021, of which $5.6 million has been incurred to date. The currently active restructuring plans are primarily in the Rest of World reportable segment. Costs incurred to date are primarily employee separation costs, while remaining costs expected to be incurred are primarily facility closing costs and other costs. The Company uses foreign currency denominated debt, a nonderivative instrument, to hedge portions of the Company’s investment in foreign subsidiaries and manage foreign currency exchange rate risk. As of June 30, 2021 and December 31, 2020, the carrying amount of the Euro denominated debt designated as a net investment hedge was $377.2 million (€317.4 million) and $391.5 million (€319.0 million), respectively.

The Company has historically used interest rate swap agreements to reduce the potential impact of increases in interest rates on the Company’s variable rate debt and to reach a desired level of fixed rate debt. These interest rate swap agreements hedged a portion of the underlying floating interest rate on the term loans associated with the Company's credit agreement and were designated as cash flow hedges. The Company's interest rate swap agreements matured on December 31, 2020. Subsubsection Title: Items Measured at Fair Value on a Recurring Basis
Subsubsection Text: Fair value measurements and the fair value hierarchy level for the Company’s liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis were as follows:

Fair value is defined as an exit price and represents the amount that would be received to sell an asset or transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants. Fair value is determined based upon inputs and assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or a liability. Fair values are categorized based on a hierarchy that prioritizes the measurement inputs as follows: Level 1: Observable inputs such as unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the Company can access as of the reporting date. Level 2: Inputs that are either directly or indirectly observable as of the reporting date, other than quoted prices in active markets. Level 3: Unobservable inputs that reflect a company’s own assumption about the information that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability.

Contingent consideration $ 1.6 $ 3.1 Level 3 The fair value of the Company’s other financial instruments, cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and accounts payable are estimated to equal their carrying value due to the relative short time between the origination of the instrument and its expected realization. The fair value of the Company’s long-term debt is estimated to equal its carrying value due to its variable interest rate. The Company is a party to various litigation matters arising in the ordinary course of business. The ultimate legal and financial liability for these matters cannot be estimated with certainty, but the Company believes, based on examination of these matters, experience to date and discussions with counsel, that the ultimate liability will not be material to the Company, its financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.

The Company’s operations are subject to certain federal, state and local regulatory requirements relating to the use, storage, discharge and disposal of hazardous materials used during the manufacturing process. Although the Company believes its operations have been consistent with prevailing industry standards and are in substantial compliance with applicable environmental laws and regulations, one or more of the Company’s current or former operating sites, or adjacent sites owned by third-parties, have been affected by releases of hazardous materials. As a result, the Company may incur expenditures for future investigation and remediation of these sites in conjunction with voluntary remediation programs or third-party claims.

On May 24, 2017, DexKo entered into an agreement and plan of merger with DexKo Holdings and Dragon Merger Sub Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of DexKo Holdings. Pursuant to the merger agreement, completed on July 24, 2017, Dragon Merger Sub Inc. merged with and into DexKo, with DexKo surviving the merger and becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of DexKo Holdings. In connection with the merger, the Company recorded a contingent liability related to the utilization of certain tax deductions that generated net operating losses. The benefit associated with these net operating losses will be paid to each security holder pursuant to the merger agreement, with payments ending in 2021 related to the 2019 tax year. In addition, the Company has recorded contingent consideration liabilities in connection with recent business acquisitions. As of June 30, 2021 and December 31, 2020, the Company’s aggregate contingent consideration liability was $1.6 million and $3.1 million, respectively, and was recorded in accrued liabilities and other and other long-term liabilities within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. -----

The Company is obligated to pay an annual monitoring fee to its two equity sponsors in return for general management, financial and other corporate advisory services and reimburse the equity sponsors for any out-of-pocket expenses incurred. The Company is also required to pay one of its equity sponsors a service fee at the consummation of each new business acquisition or divestiture. The Company records related party expenses in selling, general and administrative expenses in the condensed consolidated statements of operations. Related party expense was as follows:

The Company’s chief operating decision maker evaluates operating results and performance based on geographic areas and as a result, the Company operates in two reportable segments: North America and Rest of World. The Company’s primary products within these segments include axle assemblies, chassis, aftermarket products and other components. The Company evaluates segment performance based on external sales and Adjusted EBITDA. Adjusted EBITDA is calculated as net income (loss) before tax adjusted to exclude depreciation and amortization expense, interest expense, net and other income and expenses that management does not believe to be indicative of core operating performance. Adjusted EBITDA for each segment includes allocations of corporate costs for general, administrative, interest and other shared costs. Adjusted EBITDA is a primary measure of the Company’s ability to maintain and continue to invest in its operations and provide stockholder returns. Adjusted EBITDA may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies. Segment asset information is not provided to the chief operating decision maker; therefore, segment asset information has not been presented. Due to the nature of the Company’s operations, external sales and Adjusted EBITDA are viewed as the key measures rather than an asset base measure. Segment information was as follows:

The Company has evaluated subsequent events that have occurred after the balance sheet date through August 6, 2021, the date the financial statements were issued. On July 3, 2021, the Company’s majority equity owners, KPS Capital Partners, LP, reached an agreement to its sell its interest in DexKo to Brookfield Business Partners L.P. for $3.4 billion. The sale is expected to close before the end of the year. On July 19, 2021, the Company signed an agreement to acquire European towbar solutions specialist Brink International. The acquisition of Brink International expands the Company’s portfolio of engineered towing and carrying solutions. The transaction is subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approval. On July 29, 2021, the Company closed the sale of its damping business. ----- Deloitte & Touche LLP 200 Renaissance Center Suite 3900 # Deloitte. To the Board of Directors of DexKo Global Holdings Inc. We have reviewed the accompanying condensed consolidated balance sheet of DexKo Global Holdings Inc. and its subsidiaries (the "Company") as of June 30, 2021, and the related condensed consolidated statements of operations and comprehensive income (loss) for the three-month and six-month periods ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, and of cash flows for the six-month periods ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 (the “interim financial information").

Subsection Title: Management's Responsibility for the Consolidated Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of these consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America; this includes the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits. We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America. Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free from material misstatement. An audit involves performing procedures to obtain audit evidence about the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements. The procedures selected depend on the auditor's judgment, including the assessment of the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error. In making those risk assessments, the auditor considers internal control relevant to the Company's preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control. Accordingly, we express no such opinion. An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.

In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company and its subsidiaries as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2020 in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.

As discussed in Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements, effective January 1, 2019, the Company adopted Topic 842, _Leases,_ using the cumulative-effect adjustment transition method. March 26, 2021 -----

(“DexKo Holdings”) is the parent company of DexKo Global Inc. (“DexKo” or the “Company”). DexKo is a leading global manufacturer and distributor of engineered components critical to the safety and performance of a range of towable and related applications. DexKo offers a broad portfolio of axle assemblies, hydraulic components, chassis, aftermarket parts and other related engineered products. These products are used in applications across a diverse set of end-use segments, including agriculture, commercial, construction, general industrial, livestock, landscaping, marine, military, energy, residential, recreation vehicle and many other specialized end-use segments. DexKo sells its products directly to original equipment manufacturers, through global distributors and through its own distribution network. In March 2020 the novel coronavirus (“COVID-19”) was declared a global pandemic by the World Health Organization. The Company was negatively impacted early on in the pandemic as government-imposed lockdowns and shelter-in-place orders put in place as a response to COVID-19 led to shutdowns at several of our customers’ facilities, leading to significant declines in volume and the temporary closure of certain of our facilities throughout the world. By the end of June 2020, many countries and certain states within the United States began reopening and the Company saw significant increased demand for its products. Although demand for the Company’s products remains high, the extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic may impact the Company’s future liquidity, financial condition and operations remains uncertain.
The consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”).

The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and the wholly owned and less-thanwholly owned subsidiaries controlled by the Company. All intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. When the Company does not have a controlling interest in an entity but exerts significant influence over the entity, the Company applies the equity method of accounting.

The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts of assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes. Considerable judgment is often involved in making such estimates, and the use of different assumptions could result in different conclusions. Management believes its assumptions and estimates are reasonable and appropriate. However, due to the inherent uncertainty involved in making estimates, actual results reported in future periods could differ from these estimates.
Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash and highly liquid investments with an original maturity of three months or less.

Accounts receivable consists of amounts billed to and due from customers. The Company maintains allowances for expected credit losses as a result of customers’ inability to make required payments. Management evaluates the aging of the accounts receivable balances, the financial condition of its customers, historical trends and the time outstanding of specific balances to estimate the amount of accounts receivable that may not be collected in the future and records the appropriate provision. The allowance for expected credit losses was $3.0 million and $3.4 million as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively.

Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value. Cost is determined using the first-in, first-out method and includes the cost of materials, direct labor and allocations of variable and fixed manufacturing overhead. Management periodically analyzes inventory levels, historical usage and market conditions to determine whether there is any excess or obsolete inventory. To the extent management determines it is holding excess or obsolete inventory, the inventory is written down to its net realizable value. ----- Property, plant and equipment is recorded at cost, and depreciation is recorded over the estimated useful life of the asset using the straight-line method. Upon retirement or disposal of property, plant and equipment, the cost and accumulated depreciation are removed from the accounts and any gain or loss is included in cost of goods sold. Repair and maintenance costs are charged to expense as incurred. Intangible assets, other than goodwill, with definite lives are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives. Long-lived assets other than goodwill are evaluated for impairment if adverse events or changes in circumstances indicate that an asset group is potentially impaired. If an indicator of impairment exists, the undiscounted cash flows expected to be generated from the long-lived asset group are compared to its related net book value. If the net book value exceeds the undiscounted cash flows, an impairment loss is measured and recognized. An impairment loss is measured as the difference between the net book value and the fair value of the long-lived asset group.

Goodwill is subject to impairment testing on an annual basis, or more frequently if an event or circumstance occurs that may indicate that the carrying value may be impaired. The goodwill impairment test is performed at the reporting unit level. The Company has determined that it has three reporting units. The Company may first perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value. If management concludes that further testing is required, or if the Company elects to bypass the qualitative assessment, the Company performs a quantitative assessment by comparing the fair value of each reporting unit to its carrying value. If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, an impairment loss is recognized in an amount equal to that excess, limited to the total amount of goodwill allocated to that reporting unit. For the annual impairment tests, the Company elected to perform a quantitative test for each reporting unit. The annual impairment test was performed as of October 1, 2020, and an impairment was identified for the Hydraulics reporting unit. The estimated fair values of the other reporting units exceeded their carrying value. Refer to Note 10. Goodwill for further information regarding the impairment. There were no impairment charges for 2019 or 2018.

Subsubsection Title: Debt Issuance Costs and Debt Discounts
Subsubsection Text: Debt issuance costs and debt discounts are deferred and amortized over the term of the related debt agreement as a component of interest expense using the effective interest method. Debt issuance costs and debt discounts are recorded as a reduction to the related debt liability.

Subsubsection Title: Pension and Other Postretirement Benefit Plans
Subsubsection Text: Pension and other postretirement employee benefit costs and related liabilities and assets are determined on an actuarial basis using assumptions such as discount rates, expected returns on plan assets, compensation and other factors that are developed in consultation with our actuaries. These assumptions are reviewed at least annually and modified when appropriate. Actual results that differ from the assumptions used are accumulated and amortized over future periods, and accordingly, generally affect recognized expense in future periods.

The Company uses derivative financial instruments to reduce its interest rate and foreign currency exchange rate risk. The Company does not enter into derivative financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes. Derivatives are designated upon being established and measured at fair value. For derivatives designated as cash flow hedges, changes in fair value of the derivatives are recorded as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (“AOCI”) and subsequently reclassified into earnings when the underlying hedged transaction is realized. For instruments that are designated and qualify as hedges of net investments in foreign operations and that meet the effectiveness requirements, the net gains or losses attributable to changes in end of period exchange rates are recorded within AOCI. Recognition in earnings of amounts previously recorded in AOCI is limited to circumstances such as complete or substantially complete liquidation of the net investment in the hedged foreign operation. To the extent foreign currency denominated debt is not designated in or is dedesignated from a net investment hedge relationship, changes in value of that portion of foreign currency denominated debt due to exchange rate changes are recorded in earnings through their maturity date. ----- Assets and liabilities of foreign subsidiaries with a functional currency other than the U.S. dollar are translated into U.S. dollars using end-of-period exchange rates. Revenue and expense items are translated using weighted-average exchange rates during each period. Foreign currency translation gains and losses are included as a component of AOCI. Assets and liabilities of an entity that are denominated in currencies other than an entity’s functional currency are remeasured into the functional currency using end-of-period exchange rates or historical rates where applicable to certain balances. Gains and losses related to these remeasurements are recorded within earnings, except for those intercompany balances that are designated as long-term. The effect of foreign currency exchange rate changes on cash is reported in the consolidated statements of cash flows as a separate component of the change in cash and cash equivalents during the period.

Revenue from product sales is recognized at a point in time when control of the manufactured components is transferred to the customer in an amount that reflects the consideration the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for those products based on the purchase orders, supply agreements and volume rebate agreements. For additional information on revenue, see Note 5. Revenue.
Cost of goods sold includes material, labor and overhead costs such as depreciation, facilities expense and lease expense.

Share-based compensation is measured based on the grant-date fair value of the award, and the expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period within selling, general and administrative expenses in the consolidated statements of operations. The value of stock options is calculated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model. The Company has elected to account for forfeitures as they occur.

Research and development (“R&D”) costs are expensed as incurred and included in selling, general and administrative expenses in the consolidated statements of operations. R&D costs were approximately $15.5 million, $16.9 million and $16.7 million for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively.

Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax basis and operating loss and tax credit carry-forwards. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in earnings in the period that includes the enactment date. Deferred tax liabilities generally represent tax expense recognized for which payment has been deferred, or expenses which have been deducted in tax returns but which have not yet been recognized as an expense in financial statements. The Company establishes valuation allowances for deferred tax assets in accordance with U.S. GAAP, which provides that such valuation allowances shall be established unless realization of the income tax benefits is more likely than not. The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the periods in which those temporary differences become deductible. At each reporting period, the Company considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities, available taxes in carryback periods, tax planning strategies and projected future taxable income in making this assessment. There are two steps to recognizing and measuring uncertain tax positions. The first step is to evaluate the tax position for recognition by determining if the weight of the available evidence indicates it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained on audit. The second step is to measure the tax benefit as the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being sustained. The Company considers many factors when evaluating its tax positions and tax benefits, which may require periodic adjustments and which may not correspond with actual outcomes. The Company records interest and penalties related to income tax matters as tax expense. ----- Amounts billed to customers related to shipping and handling costs are included in net sales in the consolidated statements of operations. The Company treats shipping and handling as a cost of fulfillment and records amounts in selling, general and administrative expenses, and as a result, its gross profit and gross profit percentage of net sales may not be comparable to those of other companies that may include these costs in cost of goods sold and in the calculation of gross profit. Shipping and handling costs included in selling, general and administrative expenses were $38.0 million, $33.4 million and $41.6 million for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively.

Expenses related to advertising are expensed when incurred. Advertising expense was approximately $2.8 million, $5.6 million and $6.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively.

January 1, 2018 Plans—Defined Benefit Plans—General (Subtopic related to retirement plans by removing 715-20) disclosures that are no longer considered cost beneficial, clarifying the specific requirements of disclosures, and adding additional disclosure requirements. The Company has retrospectively adopted the standard. ASU 2018-13, Fair Value Measurement (Topic 820): Disclosure Framework— Changes to the Disclosure Requirements for Fair Value Measurement ASU 2018-02, Income Statement- Reporting Comprehensive Income (Topic 220): Reclassification of Certain Tax Effects from Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income ASU 2017-12, Derivatives and Hedging (Topic 815): Targeted Improvements to Accounting for Hedging Activities ASU 2017-09, Compensation— Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Scope of Modification Accounting Amends the fair value measurement disclosure requirements by adding, modifying and eliminating certain disclosures. The Company has prospectively adopted the amended presentation and disclosure requirements in the guidance. Permits entities to reclassify the tax effects stranded in AOCI to retained earnings as a result of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. As of January 1, 2018 the Company did not have tax effects stranded in AOCI. Eliminates the requirement to separately measure and report hedge ineffectiveness and generally requires the entire change in the fair value of a hedging instrument to be presented in the same income statement line as the hedged item. The guidance also eases certain documentation and assessment requirements and modifies the accounting for components excluded from the assessment of hedge effectiveness. The Company has adopted this guidance on a modified retrospective basis. Revenue is recognized at a point in time when control of the product is transferred to the customer under standard commercial terms, with substantially all of our sales FOB shipping point. The amount of revenue recognized reflects the consideration that the ----- rebate agreements resulting in variable consideration. The terms of a contract can give rise to variable consideration, including customer discounts, rebates and returns. The Company estimates the amount of variable consideration expected based on contract terms and does not believe that there will be significant changes to its estimates. The Company’s customers pay for products received in accordance with payment terms that are customary within the industry. The Company’s contracts with its customers do not have significant financing components.

Subsubsection Text: The Company considers purchase orders to be the contracts with its customers. A contract’s transaction price is allocated to each distinct performance obligation and recognized as revenue when or as the performance obligation is satisfied. The Company’s contracts are for the production of parts and have a single performance obligation that is satisfied when the transfer of goods or services is completed. The Company has elected the practical expedient to treat all shipping and handling activities as fulfillment costs and considers this as part of the single performance obligation. The Company applies the optional exemption to forgo disclosing information about its remaining performance obligations because its contracts usually have an original expected duration of one year or less. Payment for goods and services sold by the Company is typically due between 30 and 60 days. The Company may offer various discounts if the customer pays some or all of an invoiced amount prior to the due date. Goods that customers purchase from the Company may only be returned due to a warranty claim. Goods that customers purchase from the Company are covered by manufacturers’ warranties from the date of delivery. The Company’s warranties provide customers with assurance that purchased goods comply with published specifications. At the time revenue is recognized, the Company estimates the cost of expected future warranty claims and records such amounts as a liability. The Company maintains accounts to reflect the effects of expected future warranty claims on the Company’s financial position and periodically adjusts those accounts to reflect its actual warranty claims experience. The Company’s warranty expense is immaterial. ----- The following summarizes significant recent acquisitions. All acquisitions were accounted for as business combinations using the acquisition method of accounting. The pro forma effect of these acquisitions would not materially impact the Company’s reported results for any period presented, either individually or in the aggregate for each period presented in the consolidated statements of operations. As a result, no pro forma information has been presented. Additionally, the revenue and earnings of the entities acquired during the year ended December 31, 2020 since the date of acquisition did not materially impact the Company’s reported results. The company records costs related to acquisitions in acquisition costs in the consolidated statements of operations. Included in acquisition costs are expenses for advisory, legal, accounting, valuation and other professional fees.

During 2020, the Company acquired two businesses for total purchase consideration of $18.5 million, net of cash acquired and inclusive of $1.0 million of contingent consideration. These acquisitions did not have a material impact on the Company’s financial statements and as a result, pro forma information and other disclosures are not presented. The Company recorded $2.9 million of acquisition costs in connection with these acquisitions. In conjunction with these acquisitions, the Company recognized $6.5 million and $5.4 million of goodwill attributable to the Rest of World segment and North America segment, respectively. The goodwill is primarily attributable to the assembled workforce and expected synergies from combining operations.

In January 2018, the Company purchased all the issued and outstanding shares of E&P Hydraulics, B.V. In conjunction with this transaction, the Company also purchased the assets of E&P Hydraulics Germany and Reisemobil Service Fischer. These transactions are collectively referred to as “E&P”. The purchase price for the acquisition was $37.1 million of cash consideration. The acquisition of E&P expands the Company’s core business into leveling system solutions for caravans and motorhomes. The results of the operations of the E&P acquisition are included in the Company’s consolidated financial statements from the date of acquisition and reported within the Rest of World segment. The Company recorded $1.8 million of acquisition costs in connection with the E&P acquisition. In June 2018, the Company purchased all the issued and outstanding shares of Hume Caravan and Camping Accessories Pty Ltd and the assets of Turrisi Enterprises Pty Ltd (collectively referred to as “G&S”). The purchase price for the acquisition was $39.1 million of cash consideration. The acquisition allows the Company to expand its chassis manufacturing and further diversify the Company’s product range. The results of the operations of the G&S acquisition are included in the Company’s consolidated financial statements from the date of acquisition and reported within the Rest of World segment. The company recorded $1.9 million of acquisition costs in connection with the G&S acquisition. In September 2018, the Company purchased CBE S.r.l. (“CBE”) for cash consideration of $28.4 million. The acquisition expands the Company’s core business into electronics for leisure vehicles. The results of the operations of the CBE acquisition are ----- The company recorded $1.4 million of acquisition costs in connection with the CBE acquisition. In addition to the aforementioned acquisitions, the Company acquired two other businesses during the year ended December 31, 2018 for total cash consideration of $13.2 million. The Company recorded $2.3 million of acquisition costs in connection with these acquisitions.

The goals and investment objectives of the asset strategy are to ensure that there is an adequate level of assets to meet benefit obligations to participants and retirees over the life of the participants and maintain liquidity in the plan assets sufficient to cover monthly benefit obligations. Risk is managed by investing in a broad range of investment vehicles. The Company’s investment strategy includes a target asset allocation of 34.0% equity investments, 52.0% debt securities and 14.0% in other investment types. -----

The Company maintains a nonqualified stock option plan for eligible employees, directors and consultants of the Company and its affiliates. There are approximately 79,000 shares of Class B common stock authorized for awards granted under the Plan. The stock options are granted at an exercise price determined by the Company at the time the option is granted, which was not less than 100% of the estimated fair value of a share of common stock. The stock options have a term of ten years and vest over four years as a cumulative percentage of 25% at each anniversary over the vesting period. The grant-date fair values of the options were determined using a Black-Scholes valuation model based on the following weighted average assumptions:

The Company incurs restructuring expenses in connection with its ongoing integration of completed business acquisitions and its focus on creating a more streamlined organization to reduce costs and prepare for future growth. The Company’s restructuring activities primarily include the closure or consolidation of facilities and the reorganization of its operating structure. The Company’s restructuring charges consist of employee separation costs, facility closure costs and other exit costs such as contract termination costs, fixed asset impairment charges and equipment and personnel relocation costs. The Company expects to incur a total of approximately $6.1 million of restructuring costs related to its restructuring plans that were not substantially complete as of December 31, 2020, of which $4.8 million has been incurred to date. The currently active restructuring plans are primarily in the Rest of World reportable segment. Costs incurred to date are primarily employee separation costs, while remaining costs expected to be incurred are primarily facility closing costs. Restructuring expense by reportable segment was as follows:

On July 24, 2017, the Company entered into a Second Lien Credit Agreement (“Second Credit Agreement”) consisting of a $250.0 million U.S. Dollar denominated term loan (the “Second USD Term Loan”). The Second Credit Agreement matures on July 24, 2025 and bears interest at the Company’s option of ABR or Adjusted LIBOR plus applicable margins of 7.25% and 8.25%, respectively. The weighted-average interest rate on the Second USD Term Loan was 9.59% and 10.70% as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively.

The First Credit Agreement and Second Credit Agreement contain a number of covenants that, among other things, restrict the Company’s ability to (subject to certain exceptions) pay dividends, make distributions or make any restricted payments, incur additional indebtedness, create liens on assets, engage in mergers or consolidation and sell or otherwise dispose of assets, transact with affiliates (subject to certain exceptions), modify certain debt agreements and enter into sale and leaseback transactions. These agreements also include reporting, financial and maintenance covenants that require the Company, among other things, to comply with certain net secured and total secured leverage ratios. In addition, the agreements require certain mandatory prepayments of outstanding loans, subject to certain exceptions, based on a percentage of the annual excess cash flow of the Company on a consolidated basis (with step-downs to 0% based upon the total net leverage ratio, and with no prepayment required if annual excess cash flow is under a specified minimum threshold). As of December 31, 2020, the Company was in compliance with all financial covenants. ----- In the normal course of business, the Company is exposed to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates and interest rates. To manage a portion of these inherent risks, the Company may enter into certain types of derivative financial instruments based on management’s judgment of the trade-off between risk, opportunity and costs. The Company formally documents its hedge relationships, including the identification of the hedging instruments and the hedged items, as well as its risk management strategies for undertaking the cash flow hedges. The Company also formally assesses whether a cash flow hedge is highly effective in offsetting changes in the cash flows of the hedged items. The Company is exposed to credit risk in the event of nonperformance by its counterparties on its derivative financial instruments. The Company mitigates this credit risk exposure by entering into agreements directly with major financial institutions with high credit standards that are expected to fully satisfy their obligations under the contracts. _Net Investment Hedge: The Company uses foreign currency denominated debt, a nonderivative instrument, to hedge portions of_ the Company’s investment in foreign subsidiaries and manage foreign currency exchange rate risk. As of December 31, 2020 and 2019, the carrying amount of the Euro denominated debt designated as a net investment hedge was $391.5 million (€319.0 million) and $362.1 million (€322.3 million), respectively. _Interest Rate Swaps: The Company has historically used interest rate swap agreements to reduce the potential impact of_ increases in interest rates on the Company’s variable rate debt and to reach a desired level of fixed rate debt. These interest rate swap agreements hedged a portion of the underlying floating interest rate on the First USD Term Loan and Euro Term Loan associated with the First Credit Agreement and were designated as cash flow hedges. The Company’s interest rate swap agreements matured on December 31, 2020. The balance sheet location and fair value amounts of the Company’s derivative financial instruments were as follows:

The Company has unrecognized tax benefits of $3.6 million as of December 31, 2020, including interest and penalties. All $3.6 million would affect the Company’s effective tax rate if recognized. There were $2.4 million unrecognized tax benefits as of December 31, 2019. The Company expects no significant increases or decreases in unrecognized tax benefits due to changes in tax positions within one year of December 31, 2020.

As of December 31, 2020, the Company is currently under examination in the U.S. for periods 2015 through July 2017. The Company is no longer subject to income tax examinations in major foreign tax jurisdictions for years prior to 2014. Management considers all previously unremitted earnings of its controlled foreign corporations to be permanently reinvested due to operational and investing needs of the foreign locations. As such, no domestic income tax provision has been made for such unremitted foreign earnings. Dexter Axle Company, a subsidiary of DexKo, which owns 100% of the stock of all foreign entities, has a U.S. GAAP book basis greater than the tax basis in the stock of its foreign subsidiaries of $377.6 million. A determination of the amount of the unrecognized deferred tax liability for temporary differences related to investments in foreign subsidiaries is not practicable. ----- Net loss per share is calculated using the two-class method. Goodwill is tested at the reporting unit level. We have determined that we have three reporting units: North America, International Running Gear and Hydraulics. None of our reporting units are aggregated for purposes of the impairment test. For the 2020 impairment test, the Company elected to perform a quantitative test for all reporting units. For the North America and International Running Gear reporting units, the Company determined that the estimated fair value of each reporting unit exceeded their carrying value. For the Hydraulics reporting unit, the estimated fair value did not exceed its carrying value, and an impairment charge for the entire goodwill balance of $70.9 million was recorded. The impairment charge was the result of the impact of COVID-19 on the products, customer base, and geography of the Hydraulics reporting unit and declines in forecasted sales within that reporting unit. The Company determines the fair value of its reporting units with the assistance of a third-party valuation specialist. Fair value of each reporting unit is estimated based on a combination of discounted cash flows and the use of pricing multiples derived from an analysis of comparable public companies multiplied against historical and/or anticipated financial metrics of each reporting unit. Significant assumptions used in the estimate include market comparables, future cash flows of the reporting unit, discount rates and long-term growth rates.

On July 24, 2017, the Company entered into a First Lien Syndicated Facility Agreement (“First Credit Agreement”) consisting of a $570.0 million U.S. Dollar denominated term loan (the “First USD Term Loan”), a €350.0 million Euro denominated term loan (the “Euro Term Loan”) and a $150.0 million revolving facility (the “Revolving Credit Facility”), including a $30.0 million letter of credit sublimit facility. The First USD Term Loan and Euro Term Loan mature on July 24, 2024. The Revolving Credit Facility matures on July 24, 2022. Of the €350.0 million Euro Term Loan, €100.0 million was borrowed by the Company’s international operations. The remaining €250.0 million debt obligation was designated as a net investment hedge. Prior to the Amendment (as defined below), the First USD Term Loan bore interest based on the Company’s net total leverage ratio, as defined in the First Credit Agreement, and at the Company’s option of alternative base rate (“ABR”) or Adjusted LIBOR plus applicable margins ranging from 2.75% to 4.00%. Prior to the Amendment, the Euro Term Loan bore interest at Adjusted EURIBOR plus an applicable margin of 4.50%. The Revolving Credit Facility bears interest based on the Company’s net first lien leverage ratio, as defined in the First Credit Agreement, and at the Company’s option of base rate (“BBR”), ABR or Adjusted LIBOR plus applicable margins ranging from 2.00% to 3.50%. All amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility are available to draw until the maturity date. This facility requires a quarterly payment of a commitment fee ranging from 0.375% to 0.50% (depending on the Company’s net first lien leverage ratio) times the daily amount of applicable available unused commitment during the preceding quarter. The weighted-average commitment fee on the Revolving Credit Facility was 0.50% as of December 31, 2020 and 2019. In March 2020, the Company drew down $143.0 million on the Revolving Credit Facility to bolster its liquidity position as a proactive measure in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The entire $143.0 million drawn on the Revolving Credit Facility was repaid in May 2020. The unused balance of the Revolving Credit Facility as of December 31, 2020 was $143.6 million, net of $6.4 million letters of credit. On January 25, 2018, the Company entered into the Incremental Assumption and Amendment No. 1 to the First Credit Agreement (the “Amendment”) to modify the interest rate and increase borrowings. The Amendment reduced the interest rate from an initial applicable margin range of 2.75% to 4.00% per annum to an amended applicable margin range of 2.25% to 3.50% on the First ----- Term Loan. The Amendment increased the First USD Term Loan and the Euro Term Loan by $30.0 million and €20.0 million, respectively. In addition, the Amendment included a $50.0 million delayed draw on the First USD Term Loan and a €90.0 million delayed draw on the Euro Term Loan. The Amendment was accounted for as a debt modification. The Company incurred debt issuance costs of $3.4 million in connection with the Amendment. The Company recorded a loss on refinancing of debt of $1.5 million consisting of new and unamortized debt issuance costs, which is recorded in other (income) expense, net within the consolidated statements of operations. On September 20, 2019, the Company entered into the Incremental Assumption Agreement No. 2 to the First Lien Syndicated Facility Agreement (the “Second Amendment”). The Second Amendment provides the Company with a new tranche of Term Loans consisting of a €180.0 million Euro denominated term loan (the “Euro Term B-3 Loan”), which was used to finance the Safim acquisition. The Euro Term B-3 Loan matures on July 24, 2024 and bears interest at Adjusted EURIBOR plus an applicable margin of 4.00%. The Company incurred debt issuance costs of $4.8 million and an original issue discount of $2.5 million in connection with the Second Amendment. Subsubsection Text: Estimates of the fair value of interest rate derivative instruments are determined using exchange traded prices and rates. The Company also considers the risk of non-performance in the estimation of fair value and includes an adjustment for non-performance risk in the measure of fair value of derivative instruments. In certain instances where market data is not available, the Company uses management judgment to develop assumptions that are used to determine fair value. The contingent consideration measurement is based on the net operating loss generated by transaction tax deductions for the tax year ended July 24, 2017. For further information on contingent consideration see Note 23. Commitments and Contingencies. Fair value is defined as an exit price and represents the amount that would be received to sell an asset or transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants. Fair value is determined based upon inputs and assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or a liability. Fair values are categorized based on a hierarchy that prioritizes the measurement inputs as follows: ----- Company can access as of the reporting date. Level 2: Inputs that are either directly or indirectly observable as of the reporting date, other than quoted prices in active markets. Level 3: Unobservable inputs that reflect a company’s own assumption about the information that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability.

Benefit accruals and participation in the United Kingdom pension plan were frozen as of December 31, 2015. The Company sponsors defined contribution plans in North America. The plans allow eligible employees to contribute a portion of their compensation into the respective plan and generally provide employer contributions. Contributions were $3.5 million, $5.0 million and $3.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively.

The Company offers a long-term service award program for qualified employees at certain of its non-U.S. locations. Under this program, qualified employees receive a service gratuity (e.g., Jubilee plans) payment once they have achieved a certain number of years of service. The Company’s actuarially calculated obligation was $1.8 million and $1.5 million as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. The Company also offers salary continuation plans for qualified employees at certain of its non-U.S. locations. The Company’s actuarially calculated obligation for these plans was $0.3 million and $0.4 million as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. These liabilities are recorded within other long-term liabilities within the consolidated balance sheets.

Subsubsection Text: On January 1, 2019, the Company adopted ASC 842, “Leases,” using the cumulative-effect adjustment transition method, which does not require restatement of comparative periods. As of the adoption date, the standard resulted in recognition of additional lease assets and lease liabilities of $106.7 million and $106.9 million, respectively. No adjustment to retained earnings resulted from the adoption of the standard. The Company elected the transition package of practical expedients, which permitted the Company to not reassess prior conclusions about lease identification, lease classification and initial direct costs under the new standard. The Company also elected the practical expedient to not reassess the classification of land easements under the new standard. The Company did not elect the practical expedients related to treating lease and non-lease components as a single lease component or the use of hindsight in determining the lease term and in assessing impairment of leased assets. The Company made a policy election to exclude all leases with an initial term of 12 months or less and without a purchase option that is reasonably certain to be exercised from recognition on the consolidated balance sheet. The Company determines whether an arrangement is a lease at inception. Effective January 1, 2019, operating leases are recorded on the consolidated balance sheet, with the exception of leases with an initial term of 12 months or less. As most of the Company’s leases do not provide an implicit rate, the Company estimates its incremental borrowing rate at lease commencement date to calculate the present value of lease payments to record on the consolidated balance sheet. The Company has operating and finance leases for warehouse and manufacturing facilities, vehicles and certain equipment. The Company’s leases have remaining terms ranging from one year to 26 years, inclusive of renewal options that are reasonably certain to be exercised. Renewal options range from one year to 10 years. Some leases include options to terminate without penalty at specified periods. A portion of the Company’s facility leases are subject to annual changes based on various indexes. The changes are treated as variable lease payments and recognized in the period in which the obligation for those payments was incurred. Amounts recognized in the consolidated balance sheets consisted of the following:
Rental expense for operating leases was $20.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. -----

The Company is a party to various litigation matters arising in the ordinary course of business. The ultimate legal and financial liability for these matters cannot be estimated with certainty, but the Company believes, based on examination of these matters, experience to date and discussions with counsel, that the ultimate liability will not be material to the Company, its financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.

The Company’s operations are subject to certain federal, state and local regulatory requirements relating to the use, storage, discharge and disposal of hazardous materials used during the manufacturing process. Although the Company believes its operations have been consistent with prevailing industry standards and are in substantial compliance with applicable environmental laws and regulations, one or more of the Company’s current or former operating sites, or adjacent sites owned by third-parties, have been affected by releases of hazardous materials. As a result, the Company may incur expenditures for future investigation and remediation of these sites in conjunction with voluntary remediation programs or third-party claims.

On May 24, 2017, DexKo entered into an agreement and plan of merger with DexKo Holdings and Dragon Merger Sub Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of DexKo Holdings. Pursuant to the merger agreement, completed on July 24, 2017, Dragon Merger Sub Inc. merged with and into DexKo, with DexKo surviving the merger and becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of DexKo Holdings. In connection with the merger, the Company recorded a contingent liability related to the utilization of certain tax deductions that generated net operating losses. The liability is remeasured on an annual basis based on utilization of the net operating loss carryforward as a result of the Company’s as filed federal and state income tax returns. The gain related to the remeasurement of the liability for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 was $7.6 million and $14.8 million, respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2018, a loss of $1.2 million was recorded related to the remeasurement of the liability. The benefit associated with these net operating losses will be paid to each security holder pursuant to the merger agreement, with payments ending in 2021 related to the 2019 tax year. In addition, the Company has recorded contingent consideration liabilities in connection with recent business acquisitions. As of December 31, 2020 and 2019, the Company’s aggregate contingent consideration liability was $3.1 million and $11.5 million, respectively, and was recorded in accrued liabilities and other and other long-term liabilities within the consolidated balance sheets.

The Company is obligated to pay an annual monitoring fee to its two equity sponsors in return for general management, financial and other corporate advisory services and reimburse the equity sponsors for any out-of-pocket expenses incurred. The Company is also required to pay one of its equity sponsors a service fee at the consummation of each new business acquisition or divestiture. The Company records related party expense in selling, general and administrative expenses in the consolidated statements of operations. Related party expense was as follows:

The Company’s chief operating decision maker evaluates operating results and performance based on geographic areas and as a result, the Company operates in two reportable segments: North America and Rest of World. The Company’s primary products within these segments include axle assemblies, chassis, aftermarket products and other components. The Company evaluates segment performance based on external sales and Adjusted EBITDA. Adjusted EBITDA is calculated as net income (loss) before tax adjusted to exclude depreciation and amortization expense, interest expense, net and other income and expenses that management does not believe to be indicative of core operating performance. Adjusted EBITDA for each segment includes allocations of corporate costs for general, administrative, interest and other shared costs. Adjusted EBITDA is a primary measure of the Company’s ability to maintain and continue to invest in its operations and provide stockholder returns. Adjusted EBITDA may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies. ----- been presented. On January 19, 2021, the Company purchased all the issued and outstanding shares of Redneck Inc. and Redline Products, LLC (together, “Redneck”) for a purchase price of $175.1 million, subject to customary adjustments. The acquisition of Redneck further extends the Company’s United States distribution footprint, increases its aftermarket sales and diversifies its customer portfolio. The Company recorded $5.4 million of acquisition costs in connection with the acquisition. ----- segment, which is primarily attributable to the assembled workforce and expected synergies from combining operations.
